Response.BaseQuestion: Who are you?
Response.Content: My name is Shannon Puhalla. I am a medical oncologist at the University of Pittsburgh and I am the director of the breast cancer clinical research program.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is the BRCA gene?
Response.Content:
The BRCA [or Brach-ah gene] is actually two genes, BRCA1 and BRCA 2 and these are genes that are involved in DNA repair. If there are mutations in these genes, which we see in 5 to 10% of all breast cancer, that can predispose to breast cancer, and we talk about cancer running in families and this is one of the gene sets that may be responsible for that. We know that these genes can be inherited either from a patient's mother or from a patient's father. Sometimes people think that breast cancer only spreads through the maternal side, but that actually isn't correct. You have equal chance of either one of these genes being from either your mother or your father; and if either your mother or your father have one of these genes, the chances that you would have one of these genes is about 50%. Why having a mutation in BRCA1 or BRCA2 is important is because these mutations predispose to early onset breast cancer, bilateral breast cancer, as well as other cancers, in particular ovarian cancer. Patients who have a BRCA mutation may choose to have bilateral mastectomies instead of a single mastectomy or a single breast surgery, and in some cases we will recommend that patients have their ovaries removed as a preventative surgery as well. Currently we have not only BRCA1 and BRCA2 as genes that have been associated with breast cancer, there are actually a number of genes that have been recently discovered as potentially leading to an increased risk of breast cancer or early onset breast cancer. Sometimes the genetic counselor or your physician will talk to you about doing panel testing. What panel testing involves is looking at over 20 genes that have been associated with an increased risk of breast cancer. There are both pros and cons to panel genetic testing and this is something that will be discussed further with you if you are eligible for this testing. Patients who we refer for genetic counseling or patients who we test for BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutations are generally patients who have early onset breast cancer defined as breast cancer before the age of 45, women who have had cancer in both breasts or bilateral breast cancer, and also women who have had two or more family members with breast cancer, or one family member with ovarian cancer. These are all potential red flags that would lead us to consider that it may be that your breast cancer could be responsible for one of these mutations.
There are a number of genes that can be associated with and increased risk of breast cancer. These include BRCA1, BRCA2, PALB2, but there are over 20 other genes that we can test for if clinically indicated. This can be done either through a blood test or a saliva test.

Response.BaseQuestion: Why would you recommend neoadjuvant therapy to one of your patients?
Response.Content:
Generally, we recommend neoadjuvant chemotherapy to patients trying to capitalize on the effectiveness of neoadjuvant therapy for shrinking tumors and converting the patients from mastectomy to breast conserving surgery. But again, not everybody that is a candidate for neoadjuvant chemotherapy has to be a mastectomy candidate. We also can downstage the disease in the lymph nodes. So a patient is likely to have positive nodes, (either because we feel a node under the armpit, or because we did a biopsy up front and we know that the patient has a positive node), we can convert this patient to negative disease in the nodes, and therefore, spare them potentially from a full axillary dissection. Anybody that we can potentially minimize the extent of surgery would be a good candidate for neoadjuvant chemotherapy.
There are certain types of breast cancer that respond particularly well to chemotherapy, such as patients who have her2 positive disease or triple negative breast cancer and for those patients sometimes in particular we will often consider neoadjuvant chemotherapy in part because those tumors are likely to respond very well. We also know that the response to neoadjuvant chemotherapy is associated with long term prediction of outcome as far as prevention of breast cancer recurrence.
In many cases, if a patient is eligible for a treatment after surgery, such as chemotherapy or Herceptin based therapies, they also may have the option of receiving that treatment before surgery. There are some cancers, particularly HER2+ or triple negative that respond dramatically to chemotherapy with Herceptin (if indicated) and in many circumstances it is preferable to get the treatment prior to surgery. In addition, how well the cancers respond to the treatment, can predict overall breast cancer outcome and risk of later reoccurrence. Also as previously reviewed, patients whose lymph nodes become negative after treatment, may not need as much surgery and patients who would otherwise require a mastectomy, can be downstaged to a lumpectomy.

RQ.BaseQuestion: Why would you recommend adjuvant therapy to one of your patients?

Response.BaseQuestion: How does my doctor benefit from me being in a clinical trial?
Response.Content:
Both patients and physicians can benefit from clinical trial participation. The way that your doctor may benefit from you being in a clinical trial is that hopefully the information learned from the clinical trial helps your doctor take better care of patients in the future. And what we learn about today in clinical trials are treatments that have the potential to be better treatments and even cures for cancer in the future.
The way that I benefit from my patients participating in a clinical trial is that I know that I'm giving my patients the best possible treatment available. We always have standard treatments and for many patients standard treatments are appropriate, however for other patients or other patient circumstances, being in a clinical trial is really the best option. So as a physical I feel that when my patient is participating in a clinical trial I'm really giving them cutting edge, state-of-the-art treatment. So I know that we're really doing our best and helping not only the patient do their best but also help patients who are to come and helping patients do better over the long term.
In terms of financial compensation, both your physician and the university do receive a small amount of compensation to cover the costs associated with clinical trials. There are costs associated with the Institutional Review Board, there are also costs associated with the clinical trial nursing and this allows this to be something that we can continue to offer our patients.

Response.BaseQuestion: What are Oncotype, MammaPrint and Prosigna
Response.Content: Oncotype, MammaPrint and Prosigna are all types of genomic assays that we use to identify which ER positive cancers have a higher likelihood of recurrence and may benefit from additional treatment, namely chemotherapy. These tests are performed from the biopsy or from the resected tumor specimen, and these are tests that are performed in patients who are hormone receptor or ER or PR positive that also have 0 to 3 lymph nodes positive. These tests look at the level of important genes that determine the likelihood of the cancer to spread and the potential benefits of hormone therapy or chemotherapy. There are nuances as to which test may be ordered for you and your physician can discuss with you which test is best in your specific case.

Response.BaseQuestion: What new research is happening around breast cancer?
Response.Content:
There are a number of exciting clinical trials that we have going on really at any given time. One area of research that we are particularly interested in currently is the use of immunotherapy. Immunotherapy has made great successes in cancers such as lung cancer and melanoma and we are also studying immunotherapy for breast cancer. Particularly one type of breast cancer that has been difficult to treat is triple negative breast cancer. And there is some early data that suggests that immunotherapy, particularly combined with either chemotherapy or vaccine therapy may be particularly useful in patients who have triple negative breast cancer.
We are also focusing currently on the notion of de-escalation, so trying to sort out which patients my actually require less therapy so that we can prevent over treatment and therefore limit the amount of toxicities that patients have from their treatments.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is genetic testing
Response.Content:
Not all patients with breast cancer will need to undergo genetic testing especially if diagnosed at an older age or with limited other cancers in their family. Generally genetic testing is considered if diagnosed younger than age 45, if there is breast and ovarian cancer in your family or if more than 2 women in a family have breast cancer. Ask your doctor if your family history qualifies you for referral for genetic testing.
Patients that qualify for genetic testing may have the option to do something called "panel testing" which can look at over 20 genes associated with an increased risk of breast cancer. Testing includes the BCRA1 and BCRA2 genes, and PALB2. One downside to panel testing is that because it is newer, we do not have a lot of long term follow up data to know the exact risks with each of these genes, so sometimes patients are left with more questions than answers.

Response.BaseQuestion: Do you find that patients on a clinical trial have more side effects than patients on standard treatments for breast cancer?
Response.Content: The type and severity of the side effects you will have while on a clinical trial depends on the type of medication being tested and the type of medication you are receiving. Your doctors will explain the possible side effects to you and will monitor you closely. If you find that the side effects are unacceptable to you or become intolerable during the trial, you always have the choice to stop participating in the trial.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is cancer?
Response.Content: Cancer is not just one disease but many diseases. Cancer begins in your cells, which are the building blocks of your body. Normally, your body forms new cells as you need them, replacing old cells that die. Sometimes this process goes wrong. New cells grow even when you don't need them, and old cells don't die when they should. These extra cells can form a mass called a tumor. There are more than 100 different types of cancer. Most cancers are named for the organ or type of cell in which they start ≠ for example, cancer that begins in the colon is called colon cancer. When a cancer that starts in one place spreads to another, it's called metastases. This site discusses clinical trials that are designed to find improved treatments for breast cancer.

Response.BaseQuestion: Where can I get more information?
Response.Content: No matter how much you learn about clinical trials, you may have additional questions. Your doctor should be willing to help. Bring your questions with you to your next appointment. For more general information, try the American Cancer Society Information Service Hotline at 1-800-4-CANCER or the National Cancer Institute's website at www.cancer.gov or clinicaltrials.gov.

Response.BaseQuestion: Will I get a placebo?
Response.Content: It is not ethical to give a cancer patient a placebo with no other treatment when there is a drug known to work against their type of cancer. If you have cancer and are in a treatment clinical trial, you will receive a treatment≠ either the standard active regimen or the new treatment being tested.

Response.BaseQuestion: Introduction
Response.Content:
When you or someone you love has breast cancer, there is so much information to understand. The goal of this web site is to help you understand as much as possible about one important topic - breast cancer clinical trials - in a way that is right for you. We've brought together patients, physicians, and some additional guides, like myself, to provide answers to questions people often have about breast clinical trials. You get to ask the questions you are interested in and to hear about clinical trials directly from patients and doctors in their own words.
If you have a question that is not listed, try typing it into the box below - we may be able to answer it. If you have unanswered questions, I encourage you to take those questions to your doctor. This site is not intended to replace a conversation with your physician. Although we can't answer questions about your specific cancer diagnosis or other trials that your doctor may recommend, we hope that this site will give you more information about what it is like to take part in a clinical trial and why clinical trials are so important to consider.
If you are not sure what a clinical trial is, I suggest you start by clicking on the "Words you may hear" section. There you will find an explanation of clinical trials and related concepts.
I invite you now to explore the site and ask your questions about breast cancer clinical trials.

Response.BaseQuestion: Does being in a clinical trial affect whether patients can have reconstructive surgery?
Response.Content: The ability to be able to do reconstructive surgery on somebody generally is not affected by what kind of therapy they've had before. However, there may be certain kinds of therapies that may interfere with wound healing, and what we try to do is work someone's reconstruction around the clinical trial. Most of the time, it is not a problem.

Response.BaseQuestion: How are drug companies involved in clinical trials?
Response.Content: Drug companies are an essential part of clinical trials, because drug companies are the source for new therapies that have improved cancer treatments. Depending on the type of trial, drug company involvement can be limited to simply providing the drug for the researchers, or may extend to designing clinical trials in partnership with the Food and Drug Administration.

Response.BaseQuestion: Would being on a clinical trial be more likely to reduce patients' fertility?
Response.Content: The chances of fertility to be affected by cancer treatment are the same for patients on a clinical trial compared to patients receiving standard treatment. Chemotherapy can stop ovaries from working for a while, or in some cases permanently. It depends on the treatment if infertility is temporary or permanent. Permanent infertility is more likely in older women, especially when women are at an age when menopause would naturally occur.

RQ.BaseQuestion: Will all the risks and side effects be explained to me?

Response.BaseQuestion: What can patients expect if they receive adjuvant treatment?
Response.Content:
Adjuvant therapy is given to reduce the chance of the cancer from coming back. It is given after the primary treatment, or surgery, is done. Depending on the specific breast cancer type, different kinds of adjuvant therapies may be given, including chemotherapy, hormone therapy, radiation therapy, immunotherapy or targeted therapy.
Chemotherapy uses drugs that affect the entire body and kills cancer cells no matter where they are located.
Hormone therapy treats breast cancer that responds to hormones such as estrogen.
Radiation therapy uses X≠rays to kill cancer cells. Adjuvant radiation therapy focuses on the area around the original cancer site to reduce the risk of the cancer coming back at that site.
Immunotherapy for breast cancer is used on specific types of breast cancer, for example HER≠2 positive breast cancer. Herceptin is an immunotherapy drug called an antibody that binds specifically to the HER≠2 protein sitting on the surface of breast cancer cells.
Targeted therapy includes drugs that work to prevent specific functions in the cancer cells that are unique to a type of breast cancer.
Every adjuvant therapy can cause different side effects. Ask your doctor for the side effects that you can expect if you receive adjuvant therapy.

Response.BaseQuestion: Will I be able to work?
Response.Content: Each person's experience on a clinical trial will be different, depending on the type of medication or treatment that is being studied, the side effects of that treatment and each individual participant's reaction to the treatment. Many study participants do continue all of their normal activities, however, the side effects you experience as well as your underlying condition may affect your ability or desire to maintain your pre≠trial activities. We have asked some clinical trial participants to share their experiences and to describe what their particular clinical trials were like. Listening to some of their answers may give you an idea of how your life may be impacted while participating in a clinical trial. Click on their videos to the right to listen to their experiences.

Response.BaseQuestion: What's the next step if I agree to participate?
Response.Content:
Once you decide to participate in a trial, you will be asked to sign a consent form. Treatment will usually begin within a few days after the consent has been signed. However, it may be necessary to have additional testing performed related to your participation before treatment begins.
[Dr. Bonaventura] When I think a patient is a candidate for a clinical trial, what I normally do is explain the trial to them, and explain the rationale for the trial. Then what we do is we sit, we go through the consent form, and we go through what exactly the patient will have to deal with when she or he becomes involved in this trial. Is blood work going to be drawn? Are X-Rays going to be taken? Will measurements be taken? Whatever the trial involves, we go through that. The goal is to prepare the patient for exactly what will happen to him or her.

Response.BaseQuestion: Is there a downside to participating in a clinical trial?
Response.Content: As far as I'm concerned, there is no downside in participating in clinical trials. The studies, the clinical trials that are ready for "prime time" as we might call it, have been evaluated in animal models perhaps, in phase one trials. These drugs or treatments have already been tested and are ready to be used in large populations of patients, and I always recommend clinical trials to patients because, again, there are future generations that we need to think about, and as far as I'm concerned, there are no down...there is no downside to enrolling in a clinical trial.

RQ.BaseQuestion: Why should I participate in a trial if the standard treatment is effective?
What is the difference between standard treatment and research treatment?

Response.BaseQuestion: Would you participate in a clinical trial?
Response.Content: I can honestly say to you that if I had a disease, process, or a new diagnosis with new technologies on the horizon, I would seriously consider enrolling in a clinical trial. I would not hesitate to do that because, again, knowing the history, just of one disease, and by that I mean breast cancer, in my lifetime, the changes have been dramatic. The technologies have changed dramatically, and the treatments have changed dramatically, and because of that, I feel it is important to enroll in clinical trials, and I would definitely enroll in a clinical trial.

Response.BaseQuestion: Introduction
Response.Content:
When you or someone you love has breast cancer, there is so much information to understand. The goal of this web site is to help you understand as much as possible about one important topic - breast cancer clinical trials - in a way that is right for you. We've brought together patients, physicians, and some additional guides, like myself, to provide answers to questions people often have about breast clinical trials. You get to ask the questions you are interested in and to hear about clinical trials directly from patients and doctors in their own words.
If you have a question that is not listed, try typing it into the box below - we may be able to answer it. If you have unanswered questions, I encourage you to take those questions to your doctor. This site is not intended to replace a conversation with your physician. Although we can't answer questions about your specific cancer diagnosis or other trials that your doctor may recommend, we hope that this site will give you more information about what it is like to take part in a clinical trial and why clinical trials are so important to consider.
If you are not sure what a clinical trial is, I suggest you start by clicking on the "Words you may hear" section. There you will find an explanation of clinical trials and related concepts.
I invite you now to explore the site and ask your questions about breast cancer clinical trials.

Response.BaseQuestion: How are patients selected for a treatment trial?
Response.Content: Patients are selected for clinical trials by a series of what we call eligibility criteria. Sometimes these criteria seem sort of strict, but most of the time they're fairly straightforward. You have to have, usually, a certain stage of breast cancer, either stages I, II, or III, in some cases stage IV breast cancer. You have to generally be healthy. You have to have certain lab tests that are normal. Functions of your blood and of your liver have to be normal. And you have to have certain other criteria that are met for enrollment in the trial. One of the biggest ones is that you really have to agree to want to participate in the trial. We try to select women who are motivated. But nine times out of ten, women ask me, Is this going to be more work for me? And, it really isn't. I think the best clinical trials, the kind of trials we try to have women participate in, are the kind of trials that are basically standard of care plus something else. That's what I always tell people. It's standard of care, you get the normal care, but you, have a 50 percent or even greater chance, of getting something beyond the standard of care, that I think most women would really like to have.

Response.BaseQuestion: Is there any way to make sure I get put in the experimental group?
Response.Content: In a randomized clinical trial, all patients have an equal chance of being assigned to either treatment, and neither you nor your doctor can choose between the treatments. This is because there is no known benefit of one treatment over the other. All treatments used in a randomized clinical trial are the appropriate treatment for your type of cancer. However, if you are part of a non-randomized trial, you will always receive the experimental treatment.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What is randomization?

Response.BaseQuestion: Will there be additional tests or office visits for the trial?
Response.Content: Patients on a clinical trial are monitored more frequently than patients on standard therapy. Sometimes patients on clinical trials have additional office visits or undergo additional testing, like blood tests or x-rays and scans. Your physician and nurse will be able to provide you with information about additional testing that is required by the trial.

Response.BaseQuestion: Can I stay on my other medications?
Response.Content: The treatment offered on the trial will become your primary cancer treatment. In addition, your oncologist must review a list of all your medications, including prescribed and over-the-counter medicines, vitamins, and herbal remedies. Sometimes these medications are not permitted during cancer therapies because they may interfere with the therapy's effectiveness or have dangerous interactions. Your doctor or nurse will discuss this with you.

RQ.BaseQuestion: Are there side effects that you can't predict?
What is an oncologist?

Response.BaseQuestion: If I participate in a specific trial, will I be told if a better treatment develops?
Response.Content: Your research team will tell you about any new treatments for your cancer that may become available. Your doctor will discuss with you the benefits of one treatment over the other.

Response.BaseQuestion: Will the doctor keep me informed of how I am doing on the trial?
Response.Content: Your doctor will discuss with you how you are responding to the treatment while you are on the study and make any adjustments to your treatment based on your response.

RQ.BaseQuestion: If I participate in a specific trial, will I be told if a better treatment develops?
What if the treatment does not work?
If the medicine works for me, can I continue to receive it?

Response.BaseQuestion: When will the results of the trial be available?
Response.Content: Your doctor will provide you with information regarding the report of the entire trial when it becomes available. The final report from a clinical trial usually takes a few years to become available. However, in many trials, data are reviewed frequently so if a treatment is effective, it will be made widely available. If the treatment does not appear to work or if too many side effects are seen, the trial can either be stopped or changed.

Response.BaseQuestion: Can I exercise if I am participating in a trial?
Response.Content: It is fine to exercise when you are in a clinical trial as long as you feel well enough. Sometimes cancer treatments cause some degree of fatigue, especially when your blood counts are low. Always talk to your doctor if you plan on beginning a new exercise routine.

RQ.BaseQuestion: Will the treatment affect my appetite?

Response.BaseQuestion: Can I participate in a trial if I travel?
Response.Content: You should speak to your physician and study nurse about your plans to travel. In most cases you should be able to continue participating in the trial while working around your travel schedule.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What happens if I miss some appointments?
Can I stay in the trial if I move to a different city?

Response.BaseQuestion: Can I stay in the trial if I move to a different city?
Response.Content: If you move to another city and you are already signed on to a clinical trial, ask your research team what your options are. Many studies are conducted in several cities at the same time, and it's possible you could resume your clinical trial in another location.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What happens if I miss some appointments?
Can I participate in a trial if I travel?

Response.BaseQuestion: How many people will be in the trial?
Response.Content: The number of people in a trial varies. Some trials have as few as 15 people and others may involve thousands of participants.

Response.BaseQuestion: What happens if I miss some appointments?
Response.Content: If you anticipate a change in schedule, please contact your nurse coordinator as soon as possible to see what schedule arrangements can be worked out.

RQ.BaseQuestion: If I participate in a clinical trial do I get to make any decisions about my treatment?

Response.BaseQuestion: Will there be any follow-up after the conclusion of the trial?
Response.Content: Once the treatment period ends, the researchers will continue to follow your progress. This will be done by visits to your physician and phone calls by the research team.

Response.BaseQuestion: Will my primary doctor be updated during the study?
Response.Content: Your oncologist should update your primary care doctor about your progress. You should continue to see your primary care physician and make sure he or she knows you are participating in a clinical trial.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What is an oncologist?

Response.BaseQuestion: Has this treatment been used on other patients?
Response.Content: Generally the drugs used in clinical trials have been given to other patients. Sometimes clinical trials involve the use of drugs which have not been used in people. These are known as Phase I trials.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What do Phase I, Phase II, and Phase III mean?
Will the doctor keep me informed of how I am doing on the trial?

Response.BaseQuestion: Are trials done everywhere?
Response.Content: Trials are conducted all over the United States and the world, but not all trials are offered at all locations. Special tests or equipment or the availability of specialists are some of the factors that determine where a clinical trial is offered.

RQ.BaseQuestion: Who decides which trials are available?
Where will I go for treatment?

Response.BaseQuestion: Who funds clinical trials?
Response.Content: Many institutions and agencies support researchers through funding grants from, the National Cancer Institute, pharmaceutical companies, universities, and foundations, to name a few.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What safeguards are in place for clinical trials?
Who decides which trials are available?
What is NSABP?

Response.BaseQuestion: Who decides which trials are available?
Response.Content: Clinical trials come about because of the intellectual curiosity of physicians who see patients with problems. They'll see a patient with a problem, and wonder is there a drug that can be used to help this person, to change their lifespan, to make it longer? Is there a drug, or a technique that can be used to give them a better quality of life for the amount of time that we know they're going to have living with this disease? And it's just there,; it's just the doctors, PhDs, who develop various technologies, who have an intellectual curiosity about changing the issues that human beings have to deal with.

RQ.BaseQuestion: Are trials done everywhere?
Where will I go for treatment?

Response.BaseQuestion: What safeguards are in place for clinical trials?
Response.Content:
Even before the trial starts, the researchers must get approval from the Institutional Review Board, an organization made up of doctors, researchers, and community leaders, regarding safety and privacy concerns. During a clinical trial, the researchers are required to report to a Data Safety and Monitoring Board if any problems arise. If you have any worries about safety, talk with your doctor or nurse.
[Dr. Bonaventura] here are rules and regulations for clinical trials, and in institutions there is something called the IRB, or the Institutional Review Board, which looks at "What you want to do?" "How you want to do it?" "What is the patient population?" "How is the drug going to be administered?" "What is the technique that's going to be used?" And this board is made up of physicians, scientists, sometimes laypeople, sometimes nurses. It's an entire group of people who, sit and look at what the person wants to study, and how they want to study it. It's this group of people who sign off on the study before it even gets to the general population.

RQ.BaseQuestion: Who decides which trials are available?
Will I die?
Who funds clinical trials?

Response.BaseQuestion: Will there be side effects?
Response.Content: Most medications to treat cancer have side effects of varying degrees, whether they are used in standard care or in a clinical trial. Many side effects can be prevented or minimized and generally occur within the first days after the treatment is given. All patients are monitored very carefully for side effects. Ask your doctor or research nurse about specific side effects associated with your treatment.

RQ.BaseQuestion: Will all the risks and side effects be explained to me?
Will the treatment affect my appetite?
Are there side effects that you can't predict?
What if the treatment does not work?
Do different trials have different side effects?

Response.BaseQuestion: Are there side effects that you can't predict?
Response.Content: In any therapy, whether for cancer or another condition, some people may experience previously unknown side effects. When a person is on a clinical trial, they are watched very closely and examined for any potential side effects of the treatment.

Response.BaseQuestion: Will all the risks and side effects be explained to me?
Response.Content: When joining a clinical trial, it is the researcher's responsibility to inform you about the study - including side effects. This information is also covered in the consent form. Please do not hesitate to ask your doctor and research nurse any questions you have however big or small. Always ask if you are unsure about anything or experiencing symptoms.

RQ.BaseQuestion: Will there be side effects?

Response.BaseQuestion: What about long-term effects?
Response.Content: A number of cancer medications can have long term effects, for example heart problems, neuropathies, or increased risk for leukemia. Your doctor will discuss any potential long term effects that are known at this time associated with your trial.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is informed consent?
Response.Content: Informed consent. means that you understand the risks and benefits of the trial and that you agree to participate. A document called a consent form is given to all patients in all studies. If you have more questions about consent forms, be sure to ask your research team.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What is the consent form?
Will all the risks and side effects be explained to me?
What are my rights as a participant?

Response.BaseQuestion: Why is the consent form required?
Response.Content: The consent form is the primary safeguard for participants. It is the job of your research team to make sure that you understand what the study is about so that you can make a well-informed decision. You can talk to anyone on your team if you have any questions or need more information. Signing the consent form means that you understand the risks and benefits of the trial and you agree to begin participating in it. You should not sign the consent form until you understand it. However, you are not signing a contract. You are free to stop participating in the trial at any time you choose.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What is the consent form?

Response.BaseQuestion: What is the consent form?
Response.Content: The consent form is a document that contains all the details about a clinical trial. The consent form outlines the study treatment and potential known side effects of the treatment. It also reviews what the alternatives to the trial are, your rights as a participant including the right to withdraw from the trial, confidentiality, potential costs, and other important information.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What are my rights as a participant?
Will all the risks and side effects be explained to me?
Why is a consent form so long?
What is informed consent?

Response.BaseQuestion: Why is a consent form so long?
Response.Content:
In order to protect people who may enter clinical trials, doctors are required to fully explain what happens in the trial. Consent forms can seem overwhelming since they contain a lot of information. Your physician and study nurse will spend as much time as needed explaining the study and answering your questions. It is also helpful to take the consent form home with you so that you can review it in a more relaxed setting. Your family members may also want to review the consent form. You should not sign the consent form until you understand it. Signing the consent form means that you understand the risks and benefits of the trial and that you agree to begin participation in the trial.
Dr. Bonaventura: When I offer a patient a clinical trial, there is no pressure for them to sign the paper, give us the consent immediately. Many patients are reluctant. They're in the office for the first, maybe second time, they're alone, we present the clinical trial, we go through it as best we can with them during that period of time. Sometimes people get confused when you give them a lot of information, particularly if you start using medical jargon. What we will do is tell the patient to take the form home, read it with whoever they need to read it with and explain it to that person, have that person call and ask questions of the clinical nurse, the doctor. Perhaps come back and have another discussion. There's no pressure to enroll in a clinical trial. It's offered, questions are answered, and it's encouraged, but patients do not need to participate if they do not want to after they've thought about it.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What is a study protocol?
What is informed consent?
Could I die from participating in a trial?

Response.BaseQuestion: What are my rights as a participant?
Response.Content: When you are in a clinical trial you have rights, which are protected by the Cancer Center's Institutional Review Board, for the duration of your study participation and follow up period. These include the right to withdraw from the study at any time, without adverse effect on your relationship with your health care provider of insurance provider. You have the right to see and copy your personal health information. You have the right to be notified of any information (good or bad) that develops during the course of the study. In addition, any information about you obtained from this research will be kept as confidential as possible.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What is informed consent?
Will all the risks and side effects be explained to me?
Can I stop participating in the trial?

Response.BaseQuestion: Is my privacy protected in a clinical trial?
Response.Content:
Your treatment team will respect your right to privacy. In fact, it's protected by law. All information about the clinical trial is confidential. It is shared only with you and your research team. Only those providing your care and managing the trial will know who you are.
No one, not your employer, not even your closest family members, will know that you are participating in a clinical trial unless you decide to tell them.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What are my rights as a participant?

Response.BaseQuestion: Will I be made a "Guinea pig?"
Response.Content:
You will not be taken advantage of. Researchers do everything they can to keep you safe and informed. Unfortunately, this was not always the case. Many people have heard of the Tuskegee study and worry that it could happen again. Nowadays, researchers must be sure that participants are informed and consent to all aspects of the study.
Dr. Bonaventura: Many times when we discuss clinical trials with patients, they have many questions, and understandably so. The most common question that I hear is, or the most common comment that I hear is, "I don't want to be a guinea pig, I don't want to be tested." "I don't want to undergo any new technology that hasn't been proven," and that's when the discussion about the fact that technologies, treatments have been evaluated in the past either in patients, animals, cadaver models, whatever the technique was, and that it's already been tested and it is ready to be used in human beings. We also discuss the fact that many times, if you're talking about a new drug regimen, particularly in the management of breast cancer, you may see a change in the order of the drugs, you may see a change in the dosage of the drugs, you may see a change in the interval in which the drug is being given to the patient. So it's not.... everything is not brand new. There may be just a little tweak of the system to change things in hopes for the better.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What safeguards are in place for clinical trials?

Response.BaseQuestion: Do different trials have different side effects?
Response.Content: We already know about the side effects of many over-the-counter drugs and prescribed medications. Sometimes we don't know all the details about the drugs used in clinical trials. Your research team will tell you what they do know about the drug or drugs you will be receiving.

RQ.BaseQuestion: Will all the risks and side effects be explained to me?

Response.BaseQuestion: Will the treatment cause hair loss?
Response.Content: Many medications to treat cancer cause hair loss, also known as alopecia. If the medication you receive causes hair loss, your hair will grow back once you complete the treatments. Your health professional will discuss with you whether your medication will cause hair loss.

RQ.BaseQuestion: Will all the risks and side effects be explained to me?
Will there be side effects?
Are there side effects that you can't predict?

Response.BaseQuestion: Will the treatment affect my appetite?
Response.Content:
You should be able to eat your normal diet while you receive treatment on a clinical trial, although you may find that certain foods taste differently. You may also find that your appetite decreases during treatment. This varies with each patient. Health professionals recommend eating smaller, more frequent meals in order to meet your nutritional needs.
Lettie: I had nausea once. I only had nausea once. I had to throw up. Other than that I never had nausea, but I couldn't eat. Food tasted terrible. They told me to use plastic forks. It didn't make no difference. I'd get a taste for something, but when I got it I didn't want it. I'd take one bite and it was... nothing tasted right. And I used to love beer. I used to drink beer every day. I'd come home from work and I'd drink me a beer, but that didn't taste good even after the treatment. I still don't drink beer like I used to. Now I kind of miss that, but I don't have the taste for it like I used to.

RQ.BaseQuestion: Can I exercise if I am participating in a trial?

Response.BaseQuestion: Why do people participate in clinical trials?
Response.Content: There are many reasons people participate in clinical trials. Clinical trials can feel empowering, giving patients the chance to receive a promising new type of cancer treatment. Patients may also get closer attention from physicians and the research team. In addition, some people value the opportunity to help researchers study new ways to treat cancer.

Response.BaseQuestion: Why should I participate in a trial if the standard treatment is effective?
Response.Content:
The standard treatments we have for cancer today benefit some patients, but these treatments are not always successful. Cancer researchers are dedicated to finding better treatments and are striving for a cure, but they need the help of patients to do this. In the past several years, new drugs and treatments have been developed that ease suffering and prolong lives. These improvements in therapy are the result of patients participating in clinical trials.
Dr. Bonaventura: If individuals did not participate in clinical trials, there would be no advancement to the science of medicine. We have to think about things like; we have to think about diseases like polio. If Jonas Salk hadn't done research into the polio virus, how it was transmitted, and then ultimately come up with the polio vaccine, we would have a significant incidence of polio still in this country, and we no longer have that problem. Another disease is smallpox. We no longer have smallpox in this country, and it does exist in third-world countries, but not in this country. From the standpoint of the management of breast cancer, had those physicians not thought about decreasing the amount of surgery and treating with radiation, women would still be undergoing radical mastectomies. These operations were disfiguring and now we know, were not really necessary.

RQ.BaseQuestion: Can I get the same treatment without participating in the trial?
Why do people participate in clinical trials?
Will I be made a "Guinea pig?"

Response.BaseQuestion: Can I get the same treatment without participating in the trial?
Response.Content: New drugs or new combinations of drugs that are being tested in clinical trials are only offered in clinical trials. If you do not participate in a trial, you will get the standard treatment for your cancer if one is available.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What is standard treatment?
If the medicine works for me, can I continue to receive it?
What if there is no standard treatment for my cancer?
Why should I participate in a trial if the standard treatment is effective?

Response.BaseQuestion: What if someone said I shouldn't do the trial?
Response.Content: You may have friends and family who discourage you from joining a clinical trial. Even your family doctor may not support joining a trial. The best way to help everyone work together is to encourage these people to meet with your oncologist and nurse. They can ask questions, get more facts, and share their concerns. The research team is there to speak with anyone you choose and to assist you in making this decision. The final decision is yours.

RQ.BaseQuestion: Does it mean I am giving up if I say "no" to a trial?

Response.BaseQuestion: Can the doctor switch treatment without telling me?
Response.Content: It would be unethical for your treatment to be changed without your explicit knowledge and participation in the decision. If you have any questions or concerns, let your research team know. If your doctors decide that changes in treatment are necessary, they will explain to you why they made this decision and then ask your permission to proceed.

RQ.BaseQuestion: Will my primary doctor be updated during the study?
Will the doctor tell the truth about the trial?
If I participate in a specific trial, will I be told if a better treatment develops?

Response.BaseQuestion: Can I expect to be cured?
Response.Content: The goals of clinical trials vary. Your oncologist will talk to you about the expectations for your type of cancer. Patients who participate in clinical trials may experience a long-term remission. If your cancer is of an advanced stage, the goal of the clinical trial, or any treatment, would likely be shrinkage of your tumor and control of the symptoms associated with cancer.

Response.BaseQuestion: What if I have no insurance coverage?
Response.Content: If you have no health insurance, be careful about signing up for a clinical trial. These studies are not free, and you may eventually have to pay for treatment out of your own pocket. Having no insurance will not exclude you from participating in a trial. However, participation could quickly become very expensive.

RQ.BaseQuestion: Will my insurance coverage be affected by leaving a trial?

Response.BaseQuestion: Will my insurance coverage be affected by leaving a trial?
Response.Content: If you end up leaving a study, your medical benefits will stay the same as before. Leaving a study is your right and your doctor and nurse will respect your decisions.

RQ.BaseQuestion: Can I stop participating in the trial?
Will the doctor keep me informed of how I am doing on the trial?

Response.BaseQuestion: Will I be paid for my participation?
Response.Content: There is no payment for participating in a clinical trial, although costs for research tests and procedures required for the study may be covered by the trial. It is not common to pay volunteers any fees. This practice is clearly spelled out in the consent form.

RQ.BaseQuestion: Why do people participate in clinical trials?
What if I have no insurance coverage?

Response.BaseQuestion: What if the treatment does not work?
Response.Content: Unfortunately, there is no guarantee that any cancer treatment will work. If you enroll in a clinical trial and the treatment doesn't seem to be working, your oncologist will explore with you other treatment options you can consider.

Response.BaseQuestion: Could I die from participating in a trial?
Response.Content: As you probably know, most treatments for cancer are powerful and can cause serious problems in some patients, including, on a rare occasion, death. Doctors work hard to make sure you are as safe and comfortable as possible, whether you are on a clinical trial or getting standard therapy. Ask the research team about specific risks involved in your clinical trial.

RQ.BaseQuestion: Will all the risks and side effects be explained to me?
Will there be side effects?
Is it normal to be scared?

Response.BaseQuestion: Does it mean I am giving up if I say "no" to a trial?
Response.Content: If you decide not to join a trial, this doesn't mean you're giving up. It means that this trial isn't right for you at this time. You may feel a different choice is right for you. In many cases, standard treatments would still be available. You might consider a clinical trial at a later time.

Response.BaseQuestion: Is there an age limit to participating in a clinical trial?
Response.Content: Most clinical trials allow adults of all ages to enroll. In fact, researchers are very interested in learning more about how new cancer treatments work in specific age groups and design clinical trials accordingly.

Response.BaseQuestion: If the medicine works for me, can I continue to receive it?
Response.Content: The research protocol has clear guidelines regarding the length of time a clinical trial participant can be on a drug. The guidelines are always geared towards the patient's best interest. If a patient is doing well and side effects are tolerable, the research protocol will often allow the treatment to continue. Your oncologist will discuss this with you before you enroll.

Response.BaseQuestion: What if there is no standard treatment for my cancer?
Response.Content: If there is no standard treatment for your particular type of cancer, or if standard treatment is no longer working, talk with your doctor about the possibilities of a clinical trial. Often, people consider Phase II trials that determine how well a new drug or regimen works in a specific disease. Another option may be a Phase I trial, in which previously untested drugs are used to determine safety and gain preliminary knowledge of effectiveness.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What do Phase I, Phase II, and Phase III mean?
What are the eligibility criteria?
What is a treatment trial?

Response.BaseQuestion: Is it normal to be scared?
Response.Content: A diagnosis of cancer is very scary. If you are feeling frightened or overwhelmed, you may find that sharing your fears with your doctor or health care team is helpful. There are also support groups, social workers, and therapists who are available to discuss your feelings with you. In addition, many of the centers have reading materials, videos and other resources that you may also find helpful. Share your feelings or concerns with your health care providers.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What if there is no standard treatment for my cancer?
What if the treatment does not work?

Response.BaseQuestion: Is cancer contagious?
Response.Content: Cancer is not contagious. No one can catch this disease by being near a cancer patient. Encourage any family members who are concerned about catching cancer to speak to your health care provider.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What is a clinical trial?

Response.BaseQuestion: Do African Americans do worse than others in clinical trials?
Response.Content: There is no evidence that African Americans do worse in clinical trials. Because African Americans participate less often in clinical trials, many of the benefits from participation in trials may not have been fully realized for this particular group.

RQ.BaseQuestion: Will I be made a "Guinea pig?"

Response.BaseQuestion: What is a clinical trial?
Response.Content: In discussing treatment options, your physician may mention clinical trials. A clinical trial is a treatment program offered to cancer patients. The purpose of clinical trials is to evaluate, compare and discover new and better types of treatment. The treatment on a clinical trial is never used instead of therapies known to be effective. Sometimes clinical trials look at other aspects of cancer care such as screening, prevention and genetics.

RQ.BaseQuestion: Do African Americans do worse than others in clinical trials?

Response.BaseQuestion: What is a study protocol?
Response.Content: Every clinical trial has a protocol, a written set of rules that the physician-researcher must follow. The protocol describes what types of patients can participate, what tests will take place, the schedule of treatment, and how long the trial will last. If you would like information about a protocol, ask a member of the research team.

RQ.BaseQuestion: Barbara talks about her clinical trial.
Shannon talks about her clinical trial.
Anne talks about her clinical trial.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is randomization?
Response.Content: Randomization is an approach to assigning patients to one of the treatments being studied in a clinical trial. In randomized clinical trials, some participants receive standard treatment and others receive research treatments. Participants are assigned to the various treatments by a special computer program. Neither the patient nor the physician can choose or control which treatment is assigned.

RQ.BaseQuestion: Is there any way to make sure I get put in the experimental group?

Response.BaseQuestion: What are the eligibility criteria?
Response.Content: For clinical trials, researchers need patients who are similar on important health and disease characteristics. These characteristics called eligibility criteria. Each clinical trial has a unique set of eligibility criteria. The "matching process" will involve laboratory studies as well as other medical information about you. Usually there is no age limit for adult participation as long as you fulfill the eligibility criteria.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is standard treatment?
Response.Content: "Standard treatment" is a phrase researchers use to describe the treatments that they currently use every day to treat cancer patients. These standard treatments have already been thoroughly tested and have been shown to help some people. However, the standard treatments that we have for cancer today don't work for everyone. That is why the search for new, better treatments, made possible through clinical trials is so important.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What is the difference between standard treatment and research treatment?
What if there is no standard treatment for my cancer?
What do Phase I, Phase II, and Phase III mean?
How is participating in a clinical trial different from getting standard treatment?

Response.BaseQuestion: What is the difference between standard treatment and research treatment?
Response.Content: When researchers try new treatments, they compare the research treatment with the standard treatment. A standard treatment is a treatment that has already been demonstrated to benefit patients. A research treatment is a new treatment that is hoped to be better than the standard treatment, but requires more testing to prove this. A trial that compares standard treatment with a research treatment is usually a Phase III trial.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What is standard treatment?

Response.BaseQuestion: What is a placebo?
Response.Content: A placebo is a drug containing no active ingredients, such as a sugar pill, that may be used in clinical trials to determine the effects of a research treatment. It is not ethical to give a cancer patient a placebo when there is a known effective treatment. You will be told if a placebo is being used in your trail.

RQ.BaseQuestion: Will I get a placebo?

Response.BaseQuestion: What do Phase I, Phase II, and Phase III mean?
Response.Content:
After lengthy testing in laboratories, promising treatments are ready to be tested on people for the first time. This is called a Phase I clinical trial. In Phase I, researchers try to find how much of a drug can be safely given, and what the likely side effects are.
In a Phase II trial, researchers ask the question "Is this drug effective in treating cancer?" In Phase II, researchers determine how well the drug works against a specific type of cancer and continue to watch for side effects.
A Phase III trial compares a new effective treatment with the currently best available treatment - also known as "standard treatment". A Phase III trial is the only way to learn which of the treatments is better.

RQ.BaseQuestion: Where will I go for treatment?
If I participate in a specific trial, will I be told if a better treatment develops?

Response.BaseQuestion: What is a dosage escalation trial?
Response.Content: In a Phase I trial, the starting dose of a medication is based upon laboratory studies. Usually, the dose starts low and then increases if the dose doesn't cause serious side effects. This process, called "dosage escalation," is done so that the most appropriate dose for patients can be determined.

RQ.BaseQuestion: Has this treatment been used on other patients?
What is a prevention trial?
What is a screening trial?
What is a treatment trial?
What is a Quality of Life Trial?
What are genetic studies?

Response.BaseQuestion: What is a prevention trial?
Response.Content: Prevention clinical trials study the risks of developing cancer and often test new drugs designed to prevent cancer. These trials usually involve people who have never had cancer, although some of these trials may involve patients who have had cancer before or hope to reduce the risk of a new cancer.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What is a screening trial?
What is a treatment trial?
What is a Quality of Life Trial?
What are genetic studies?
What is a dosage escalation trial?

Response.BaseQuestion: What is a screening trial?
Response.Content: Screening trials test ways to detect cancer as early as possible - even before symptoms appear. Screening trials are conducted with a wide variety of people in an effort to detect cancer before it spreads so that it is more easily treated.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What is a prevention trial?
What is a treatment trial?
What is a Quality of Life Trial?
What are genetic studies?
What is a dosage escalation trial?

Response.BaseQuestion: What is a Quality of Life Trial?
Response.Content: As part of your clinical trial, you may be asked to complete surveys about the quality of your day-to-day life and how it may have changed with your treatment. This helps researchers better understand the impact of cancer and cancer treatment.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What is a prevention trial?
What is a screening trial?
What is a treatment trial?
What are genetic studies?
What is a dosage escalation trial?

Response.BaseQuestion: What is a treatment trial?
Response.Content: Treatment trials are used for people who have already been diagnosed with cancer. Researchers use treatment trials to test new drugs, vaccines and therapies that may slow or even stop the spread of cancer in a person's body. Treatment trials may also try new combinations of standard treatments or newly discovered drugs.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What is a prevention trial?
What is a screening trial?
What is a Quality of Life Trial?
What are genetic studies?
What is a dosage escalation trial?

Response.BaseQuestion: What are genetic studies?
Response.Content: Genetic studies are different from clinical trials. Because cancer may be passed down in families, studies of our genes may help us understand cancer. Such genetic studies may also help predict the risk of developing cancer. Some genetic studies evaluate specific genes in cancer tissue which may help investigators understand why certain drugs are effective.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What is a prevention trial?
What is a screening trial?
What is a treatment trial?
What is a Quality of Life Trial?
What is a dosage escalation trial?

Response.BaseQuestion: What is an oncologist?
Response.Content: An oncologist is a doctor who specializes in treating cancer patients. Oncologists have spent many years after medical school learning about cancer.

RQ.BaseQuestion: Who decides which trials are available?

Response.BaseQuestion: Is there a support group for people considering or participating in a clinical trial?
Response.Content: There are no support groups specifically for people participating in a clinical trial. However, there are many support groups for cancer patients. Ask your research team about support groups, social workers and psychological counseling in your area.

RQ.BaseQuestion: Is it normal to be scared?

Response.BaseQuestion: Will I be given medication to reduce side effects?
Response.Content: Every effort is made to minimize side effects. This includes medications to decrease nausea and vomiting.

RQ.BaseQuestion: Do different trials have different side effects?
Will the treatment affect my appetite?

Response.BaseQuestion: General Offtopic
Response.Content: We're here to talk about clinical trials, and I'd be happy to talk to you about that.

Response.BaseQuestion: Anne talks about her clinical trial.
Response.Content: The first time around my doctor offered me a clinical trial, and I was really just too frightened and too freaked out by the whole situation to read all the information about the clinical trial. And, I regretted that. I thought that it really limited my treatment options; and, because I wouldn't read the material. So, I always thought to myself, if I had a recurrence, I would definitely, seriously consider a clinical trial. And, so when I did have the recurrence, my doctor said, I have a clinical trial that I think would be very helpful to you.

Response.BaseQuestion: Barbara talks about her clinical trial.
Response.Content:
When I first met my oncologist I really didn't think I was going to get x-chemotherapy because of the size of the lump and what my surgeon said. So when I first met my oncologist he told me I was going to get chemotherapy. I cried so bad that he told me, Okay, you go home and I'll see you in a week so you can calm down. I guess I scared him so bad that he didn't know whether to finish talking to me or what. When I came back the next week he explained everything that was going to take place and he offered me a clinical trial research.
They wanted to monitor women with breast cancer that was diagnosed with negative nodes. Every time I would go see my oncologist when I was in the clinical trial, I would get a full examination, I would get my blood work taken, I would spend time with my oncologist, he would make sure only blood work came back good, nothing was wrong, and I would go get my chemotherapy, and if he seen any problems he would address it quickly. I felt very comfortable.
The study last from September of 2005 to January of 2006, but I'm still in a study and I guess it's going to go for the next four or five years. They're still going to keep track of me. I go every couple of months to get blood work taken, to see my oncologist, to get a physical exam. At this time I come to the clinic every six months to get my blood work taken, to see my oncologist, to talk to him to see if anything has changed.

Response.BaseQuestion: Shannon talks about her clinical trial.
Response.Content:
I heard about the clinical trial when I was in the hospital. I had broken my hip and that was how they actually found the cancer. And I had someone talk to me and give me options, and one of them was the clinical trial.
Well it's one study, but there's two different studies within the group. And then you just do a flip of the coin, and I got the two drugs as opposed to the other two drugs that they're doing. So it's one study, but it's two different; it is two different studies technically I guess.
As far as right now, because they're going to keep doing it until something changes, so my clinical study is just going to continue until either I do worse, where, I mean, you know, the tumors aren't decreasing. So, I just keep doing the same study.

Response.BaseQuestion: Anne describes what was involved in her clinical trial.
Response.Content: The treatments were; so I would arrive for my appointment, and I would have an examination by the doctor, and then I would have my blood drawn, just to see what my blood counts were. And, then I would be administered the drugs, intravenously, and that usually lasted maybe an hour and a half, two hours. And, then every three months, I would have some sort of a scan, just to make sure that things were going in the right direction, which was shrinking.

Response.BaseQuestion: Shannon describes what is involved in her clinical trial.
Response.Content:
So, I go on day one and I get two chemos that are IVs, and then a week later, on day eight, I get one chemo and then I get a week off, basically to get my body back; to rejuvenate myself after having all the chemos. So, that's my cycle, I go one week, one week, and off.
Yeah, I go every nine weeks. I get scans, either CT scans, PET scans. Of course I'm sure it depends on what type of cancer you have, what type of scans you're going get. In my case I get those type of scans and they do those every nine weeks. And then they compare those, you know, with prior ones, to see what the results are. Whether or not progress, no progress, anything changed or not changed.

Response.BaseQuestion: Barbara tells how often she visited the clinic.
Response.Content: When I was on a clinical trial, I went to the clinic every three weeks and I would get my blood work taken, I would go see my oncologist, he would wait for my blood work to come back to check it to make sure that everything was right, and then I would go to get my chemotherapy.

Response.BaseQuestion: Anne tells how often she had to come to the clinic.
Response.Content: So, every clinical trial has its own protocol. So, for me the regiment that I was on; every three weeks, I started a new round of chemotherapy. And within those three weeks, the first week I got what I called, the big chemo, which was about an hour and a half, two hours. And, then eight days, seven days later I would come in for little chemo. which was about, maybe an hour, maybe half an hour long. And then the third week I was off.

Response.BaseQuestion: Lettie describes the quality of the care she received on the clinical trial.
Response.Content:
I think I had excellent care. If I didn't have my clinical nurse on top of things I don't think I would be here today. As a matter of fact my heart doctor told me that every day he wanted me to do something good for somebody because I was given a second chance because I out of his hands. That's what my cardiologist told me. And if she hadn't stayed on me, called that doctor and he called me, I probably wouldn't be here today.
I think I was watched very closely. They were on it, they were on it. Especially my clinical nurse, she was on it, and she would call me sometimes, "How are you feeling?" I mean, I don't have an appointment or anything, but I was complaining. I had a complaint and she would call me in-between, "How are you feeling, Do you have..." you know, asking me questions and stuff. She said, "I'm concerned about you." I said, "You don't have to be concerned about me. I'll see you when I get to the next doctor's appointment," you know, but she, it didn't stop her. She called.

Response.BaseQuestion: Anne describes the quality of the care she received on the clinical trial.
Response.Content: In both instances, I received excellent care. But how it differed on the clinical trial, was because I was part of a research study, there were more people who were involved in my care. And, because I was part of a research study, they were collecting information, you know, wanted to know how I felt, you know, based on the drugs, those sorts of things. However, these people, the hospital personnel turned out to be wonderful in terms of their support, and, they were very kind, and they were very caring. So regardless of whether I was getting a clinical trial or standard care, they were still; they really became part of my support group.

Response.BaseQuestion: Shannon describes the care she receives on her clinical trial.
Response.Content: There's nurses all over, I would assume I could ask the doctors if I ever had a question, I've never actually come across a time that I had to but, there's nurses all in the facility that actually, you know, do the treatments, give the treatments to the patients, so they're always available. ;there's a 24 hour phone number you can call. If for some reason I needed to call and I couldn't get a hold of my clinical study nurse, I could call and get someone else who could answer my questions. So I've never run into a problem where I can't find someone to help me.

RQ.BaseQuestion: Lettie describes the quality of the care she received on the clinical trial.
Anne describes the quality of the care she received on the clinical trial.
Shannon describes the care she receives on her clinical trial.

Response.BaseQuestion: Anne explains why she participated in a clinical trial.
Response.Content:
I thought it was my best treatment option. I thought it was going to; I thought it was my best treatment option. And, probably my doctor. He just, he felt that I would benefit from being in this trial, and because he's been my doctor for over six years, I know the reputation he has as a researcher, that he does, has done a number of clinical trials, I just thought that this would; that he knew what he was doing and that this would be a good thing for me.
So, well, the benefit to me is, if this drug works, I'm right there on the cutting edge, getting all the benefits of the drug therapy. As well as, for other people, they'll have that information. So it worked for this population of people, and you know, they; they've done very well, and so, it might ultimately be effective enough treatment that it becomes standard care, until something better comes along.

Response.BaseQuestion: Shannon explains why she decided to participate in a clinical trial.
Response.Content: Well, I would like to see that, you know, obviously you want to see a cure, but I would be more realistic in hoping that maybe the treatments that I'm receiving and the combination of drugs they're using on me, will benefit someone else with the same type of cancer that I have. So, whether or not it does help somebody in the future, I really want it to help me first. So, I'm more concerned about me. But on the other hand, I'll do my good deed for society and you know, do the clinical study. Which is why I participated in it; which is why I'm sitting here talking to you guys; against my better judgement.

Response.BaseQuestion: Barbara explains why she participated in a clinical trial.
Response.Content: Because me, as being an African-American woman, wanted them to have some research on African American women to help with the medication, the type of treatment that we, that they can give us to help us. Looking back on it, yes I believe it was the best thing for me to do. Would I do it again? Yes I would.

Response.BaseQuestion: Lettie explains why she decided to participate in a clinical trial.
Response.Content: My daughter-in-law, she, well I went home and I talked to my family about the trial, you know, what I should do, and my daughter-in-law, she said, "Well I think they'd follow you closer if you was on the trial." And like, when you say cancer, it's like a scary something anyway. You know, it's just something like, you don't expect to hear it happening to you. I talked about everything with my family, everything, from day one, from the day I was diagnosed. My family was there with me for every treatment, everything. Every time with the doctor there was a family member there with me. Whatever I had to do there was family there. She said, my daughter-in-law felt like, "Maybe you should give it a try." And I did.

Response.BaseQuestion: Barbara discusses her concerns going into the clinical trial.
Response.Content: The first time I heard about a clinical trial for my breast cancer I was scared. I didn't know what to expect. When you hear of trials, clinical trials, you hear of either they give you the right medicine or they give you a placebo or something other than the medicine and I was a little scared.

Response.BaseQuestion: Shannon talks about her concerns going into the clinical trial.
Response.Content: Just, I was more, probably more concerned about restrictions, things I could or couldn't do. There really is no down side to the clinical study as far as I'm concerned. It's a; it's going to help somebody in the long run, and its helping you currently, so I don't really see that there was any real reason not to do it. So my concerns were pretty minimal.

Response.BaseQuestion: Anne on her concerns going into the clinical trial.
Response.Content: I really didn't have any concerns about participating in the clinical trial, the second time around. The first time around it wasn't so much that I was afraid that I was just going to be treated as a research subject. It was more that, the whole idea of being treated for cancer and having to choose, because I had options; having to choose and not being very educated in this area. That bothered me. But the second time around, you know, I just had a little bit more information. And I just knew a lot more about the benefits of a clinical trial. The benefit, the largest benefit being for myself, but also the benefit that it would ultimately be for others who came behind me.

Response.BaseQuestion: Anne talks about the consent form.
Response.Content: Well, it's not unlike buying a car. All those forms that you have to sign. And; but in terms of going along with my car analogy, I think that participating in a clinical trial, they do try to do a little bit better job of explaining everything to you. I think it's overwhelming, because it's a; you're in a very overwhelming position.

Response.BaseQuestion: Shannon talks about the consent form.
Response.Content: Big words, a lot of big words in the consent form. Again, you're overwhelmed about your diagnosis, and then you get this consent form and you're reading it and you're thinking Oh I don't know what this word means. So if you have someone to; again, your clinical study nurse, or a spouse or someone to read it with you, to ask questions. Once you get that information cleared up, what the big words mean, it's really not, I mean the overall package, was very easy to read. But there's a lot of information in there and I read mine over and over and over again. But it was, you need to do some type of research on it.

Response.BaseQuestion: Barbara talks about reading the consent form.
Response.Content: When I first saw the consent form I was very scared. I felt that once I signed this paper I was giving them control over my life. But I felt comfortable with my oncologist, the way he explained everything and what would take place. So me, my mother, and my sister we sat down and we discussed it and I signed it. I signed the consent form. My hand wasn't in shaking.

Response.BaseQuestion: Lettie talks about the consent form.
Response.Content: Yeah, when I read it I understood the consent form. That's why I didn't sign it right away. I wanted to look it over. They gave me the opportunity to look it over and think about it. I didn't have to sign it right away, but they wanted me to sign it before my first treatment.

Response.BaseQuestion: Anne talks about how participating in the clinical trial differed from her expectations.
Response.Content: I didn't have a lot of expectations about what the trial; how the trial would be going into it. But I was surprised at how closely I was monitored. And, every time I went in for a visit, one of the nurse coordinators always came around to the chemo chair to see how I was doing, and we'd usually spend half an hour talking. And maybe it would be 10 or 15 minutes talking about how am I feeling, those sorts of things. Talking about my blood results, the results from my blood test, and then the other 20 minutes was just talking about everyday life and what was going on with their family and what was going on in my life. And so, probably the one thing that I, while I didn't have an expectation of this, one of the pleasant surprises was that these people became; you know, these people became part of my support group and they became friends.

Response.BaseQuestion: Barbara discusses how her participation was different than she expected.
Response.Content: Participating in a trial was very different than I expected to be. They were, they cared about me. They cared about what I did yesterday, how I felt. They talked to me about the treatment I was getting each and every time I went even though after while I started knowing what it was. They made me feel comfortable all the time. And it was different. I expected something; just go in there and get my treatment, go home, be sick. They made sure I got the right nausea medicine. They changed it a couple of times. They were special.

Response.BaseQuestion: Did Barbara ever feel like a Guinea pig during the clinical trial?
Response.Content: When I was first asked about the clinical trial I did think they were using me as a guinea pig, but once I entered the clinical trial research and I came in the company of the people that were taking care of me and that did the research, I was treated special ; like a person, not a number or just a guinea pig, but a person with feelings, concerns, fears.

Response.BaseQuestion: Did Anne ever feel like a Guinea pig during the clinical trial?
Response.Content:
I didn't know a lot about clinical trials before my first diagnosis. And, I probably had in my head just about all the myths that you can imagine that go along; that people are trying to break down now about clinical trials. So, the whole myth about being a guinea pig, and; to some degree, you are a research experiment. I mean, you go into this and people are studying how you respond to a certain protocol. But it's much bigger than just being a research experiment. They're trying to provide you with the best therapy possible, and the best care possible.
I was treated very well. I was treated with a lot of respect. And I was treated with kindness, and a lot of compassion. They see a lot of; they see a number of patients every day, and people are very, very fearful, and they are very skilled in making people, making a very anxious time less anxious.

Response.BaseQuestion: Does Shannon ever feel like a Guinea pig in the clinical trial?
Response.Content: I feel I'm treated just like everybody else. I mean I'm not; I'm not treated any differently because I'm in a clinical study. The facility I go to treats everyone wonderfully. So on a personal level, you know, I'm not treated any differently than anybody else. I don't have a, you know, big tag on me that says, clinical study, treat me differently.

Response.BaseQuestion: Did Lettie ever feel like a Guinea pig during the clinical trial?
Response.Content: I felt that way. I felt like, when I first started looking at the thing, I thought I was, they'd use me as a guinea pig. I said, "I ain't, I don't want to be..." But then my daughter-in-law kept saying, "But they're going to watch you." Because she told me her sister works with these different studies and stuff and she had talked to her and she told her, "They'll really watch her. They will really watch her with that." I felt like we were being used in a certain way with the studies, but I had the option. I didn't have to take it. So if they used me as a guinea pig, it's my, me who done that not the doctors per say because I didn't have to sign that consent form.

Response.BaseQuestion: Shannon talks about communication with her doctor.
Response.Content:
My doctor is wonderful, I mean he's very knowledgeable in the field, so he's; again he gave me information about the clinical trial and made me feel comfortable with it. And explained, you know, my type of cancer, and how this would, you know, benefit me and others if I participated it in. So, he's; I love my doctor.
No he talks to me like a regular person, because I told him, don't use big words. No he's; I have a very good relationship with my doctor so, I can't you know; I may have a different type of relationship than other type of people. I joke around with my doctor. So I may not have the same that other people do.

Response.BaseQuestion: Was the doctor always open to Anne's concerns?
