Response.Content: Oh yes, they were very open to all of my concerns. I did have some concerns. One of the concerns was, sometime my white blood cell count was too low to get a treatment, and because of the clinical trial protocol, if you drop below a certain number, they generally don't like to treat you. And, that bothered me a little bit. But in talking with my doctor, he always would go back to the pharmaceutical company who was also participating in the trial, and generally speaking, even if it was for that day, a reduced dose, I always got a treatment. And that made me feel a lot better. Because, I never wanted to go to the hospital and not be treated.

Response.BaseQuestion: Barbara talks about how the doctor communicated with her.
Response.Content: My oncologist was open to each and every fear and concerned that I had about this clinical trial research. When we first talked about the clinical trial research my oncologist didn't talk on my level. I didn't understand a word he was saying until I told him, I don't understand. and then he brought it down to my understanding and made it clear for me to understand what would take place in this clinical trial research.

Response.BaseQuestion: What was the most difficult part of Barbara's clinical trial?
Response.Content: The most difficult part of participating in the clinical trial research was the chemotherapy. It made me sick each and every time that I took it, but I knew it was what it took to make me better. I felt like quitting the whole thing, the chemotherapy, the doctor's appointments, everything, but my doctor always encouraged me and told me that it would get better.

Response.BaseQuestion: What difficulties did Anne have during the clinical trial?
Response.Content: The only difficulties that I experienced on the trial, was when my white blood cell count did drop. And, for about two or three days, I would feel tired; lack of motivation, crabby. But, other than that, I was able to continue on with a regular routine.

Response.BaseQuestion: Anne discusses her side effects on the clinical trial.
Response.Content: One side effect of most chemotherapy treatments is nausea. And I was given a number of drugs to try if I happened to experience a lot of nausea. I personally did not have a lot of nausea. What I experienced more was, when my white cell count was low, I felt like I was coming down with the flu for two or three days. And, so I would take Tylenol and I would drink some sort of like a Gatorade type drink, and that helped quite a bit. But I was very fortunate. My side effects on this clinical trial were very small and they were very tolerable.

Response.BaseQuestion: What side effects does Shannon experience on the clinical trial?
Response.Content: I have the same side effects I think that you would get regardless of the clinical trial. I get the same side effects from chemotherapy. I get the flu like symptoms, fatigue, because of my type of cancer I have bone issues, so I get very achy, tired is probably my main; I do not get sick, no vomiting, because I do get pre-meds before the chemo, so that eliminates any type of nausea. And I do have a prescription for that also, but I don't actually get sick to my stomach.

Response.BaseQuestion: Barbara talks about the side effects she had during her clinical trial.
Response.Content: I got sick. My hair fell out. My doctor encouraged, well reassured me that my hair was going to grow back again and I was going to be fine. I was going to get through this. Here I am today. My last treatment was January the nineteenth.

Response.BaseQuestion: Has Shannon ever thought about quitting the clinical trial?
Response.Content: No, I don't want to quit. I mean, I don't want to quit for two reasons, one because this is what's keeping me alive, and two this is what I want to do. I want to make sure this study sees to the end and what results come from it. So I don't want to quit, actually I'm very, you know; If I stop for whatever reason I get very hyper because I don't want to get kicked out. So yeah, I don't want to quit the study.

Response.BaseQuestion: Did Anne think about dropping out of the clinical trial?
Response.Content: I never considered dropping out of the trial. My biggest fear would be that, for whatever reason, that something would happen and I would cease to be eligible to participate in the trial.

Response.BaseQuestion: Can Shannon quit the clinical trial?
Response.Content: That's one of the things that's made very clear in the beginning. You can quit the study any time, by your own choice, because you just can't stand the side effects, or a doctor can pull you out if they think the study is not helping you personally. You're the main priority, so if the study is not helping you, they're not going to keep you in it just for the sake of the study. So if it's not helping you, they can pull you out of it and they will just do an alternative type of treatment. So the feeling that you're stuck in it, is just not there. You can just quit anytime you want.

Response.BaseQuestion: Did Barbara know she could quit the clinical trial?
Response.Content: When I was first presented with the clinical trial research, they told me at any time I can come out of the treatment ; I mean, come out of the research, yes.

Response.BaseQuestion: Did Anne know she could quit the clinical trial?
Response.Content: Yes. If I had wanted to quit, I could have quit. But, I never did think about it. Because it was going very well for me, and so it wasn't, I was tolerating the chemotherapy well. I was able to continue to do my normal routine. I basically had no restrictions, other than just use some common sense, you know, when my white blood cell count was low. But, if it ever got to the point where, where, you know. It was pretty clear, from talking with my oncologist at the beginning of the trial, that if this trial didn't work well for me, that we would make the decision together about whether to quit or not. And whether, and seek some other type of therapy. So I always felt very comfortable.

Response.BaseQuestion: Would Shannon participate in a clinical trial again?
Response.Content: Oh, I would do it again. I would prefer not to have cancer, but yeah, if I had to do it again. I mean, you know the, if it's going to help me, yeah. If it's going to help me, I would do it again, and if it's going to help somebody else, yes I would do it again.

Response.BaseQuestion: Does Barbara think participating was worth it?
Response.Content: Looking back on it, yes I believe it was the best thing for me to do. Would I do it again? Yes I would.

Response.BaseQuestion: Does Anne think her participation was worthwhile?
Response.Content: Yes, I think it was very worth it to participate. I responded well. And, if I had to do this again, I would, if a clinical trail were offered to me, I would definitely consider taking it again.

Response.BaseQuestion: Would Barbara recommend a clinical trial to a friend who was considering participating?
Response.Content:
If I knew someone that was diagnosed with cancer and they were offered the opportunity to participate in a clinical trial research I would encourage them to participate.
What I think we gain with people participating in clinical trial research is the doctors, the medical field getting the information they need to help us as citizens or people with cancer, better treat us, better diagnosis.
If someone asked me my opinion about being in a clinical trial research, I would encourage them to join the research. Why would I encourage them? My personal opinion is that think you'll be treated better. They'll look at you closer. They'll watch your blood work, how you reacting to the treatments, and they'll get some information that they need too but I think it's a benefit to you to join the clinical trial research.

Response.BaseQuestion: Would Anne recommend clinical trial participation to a friend?
Response.Content:
I would definitely recommend a clinical trial to, This is what I would recommend, if they are diagnosed with cancer, or any other kind of a disease, where they are eligible for a clinical trial, I would definitely recommend that they stay open to hearing everything about the trial, what the aims of the trial are, as well as also understanding what the current standard treatment is and what that will provide for them as well.
I guess, what I would just, what I would reiterate is, clinical trials are another treatment option, and they often provide you with the latest and the greatest therapies that are being looked at. And they can provide a lot of benefit, and so they're definitely something worth exploring.

Response.BaseQuestion: Shannon's words to others who are considering participating in a cancer clinical trial.
Response.Content:
Well, you already have cancer, it's a done deal. It can't get any worse, period. So you got to have choices, and if you have the choice of a clinical trial, then what's it going to do? It can't hurt you, as long as you're well informed and you understand what you're getting into, it can't hurt you, you've already got cancer. You should, at that point it's getting better and helping other people. And if you can do both at the same time, I think that's a pretty good deal.
There's, I mean, I just think the clinical study is just the perfect opportunity to you know, help yourself, and to help medical science. I mean, its, there's no real reason not to do it. I don't know why you wouldn't do it. I'm sure there is. I'm sure that somebody has come up with a reason not to do it, or there would be more people doing it probably. But I couldn't come up with a reason not to do it. It's helping me personally, you know, currently I'm involved in it, and it's helping me so, I would suggest it to anybody.

Response.BaseQuestion: Lettie's advice to others considering clinical trial participation.
Response.Content: The only thing I can tell anybody about clinical trials is do your homework, think it over, and see whatever is the best thing for you. I wouldn't advise no one to just sign the papers. Think about what is best for you. Do you think this may help you? And being that my sister had breast cancer five years before I got breast cancer.

Response.BaseQuestion: How did Barbara make the decision to participate in her clinical trial.
Response.Content: How I went about making a decision about entering the clinical trial was my family. My family, my mother and my sister, we talked about it. My sister and my mother accompanied me to each and every doctor's appointment, chemotherapy treatment, yes.

Response.BaseQuestion: Barbara's message to the African-American community regarding clinical trials.
Response.Content: What I would say to the African-American community about clinical trials is that there's no reason to be scared anymore. They're not using us as guinea pigs. They're trying to find out what's the best medication and what's the best that they can do for us. And I think that's the main reason I joined the clinical trial research is that I was an African-American woman feeling like they don't know much about us. So that's why I joined. And I would encourage other African-Americans to join clinical trial research.

Response.BaseQuestion: Lettie talks about her side effects during the clinical trial.
Response.Content: I had nausea once. I only had nausea once. I had to throw up. Other than that I never had nausea, but I couldn't eat. Food tasted terrible. They told me to use plastic forks. It didn't make no difference. I'd get a taste for something, but when I got it I didn't want it. I'd take one bite and it was, nothing tasted right. And I used to love beer. I used to drink beer every day. I'd come home from work and I'd drink me a beer, but that didn't taste good even after the treatment. I still don't drink beer like I used to. Now I kind of miss that, but I don't have the taste for it like I used to.

Response.BaseQuestion: Who are you?
Response.Content: My name is Anne and I've been diagnosed with breast cancer. And, I've actually had two diagnoses. In 1999 I was diagnosed at the age of 35 with breast cancer, and then in 2004 I was diagnosed with a recurrence.

Response.BaseQuestion: Who are you?
Response.Content: My name is Barbara and I was diagnosed with breast cancer.

Response.BaseQuestion: Who are you?
Response.Content: My name is Lettie and I was diagnosed with cancer of the left breast.

Response.BaseQuestion: Who are you?
Response.Content: My name is Shannon and I have breast cancer.

Response.BaseQuestion: Anne tells us with whom she discussed participation.
Response.Content: I did not seek any help with the consent form. And, I also did not talk to my family about whether or not I should be in the clinical trial because I felt that this is my decision, and this is a decision between me and my oncologist. And, I felt very firm about that. And, I really did not want to get into a position where I had friends and family weighing in on what they thought I should do.

Response.BaseQuestion: Dr. Bonaventura talks about how she approaches the subject of a clinical trial with a patient.
Response.Content: When I think a patient is a candidate for a clinical trial, what I normally do is explain the trial to them, and explain the rationale for the trial. Then what we do is we sit, we go through the consent form, and we go through what exactly the patient will have to deal with when she or he becomes involved in this trial. Is blood work going to be drawn? Are X-Rays going to be taken? Will measurements be taken? Whatever the trial involves, we go through that. The goal is to prepare the patient for exactly what will happen to him or her.

Response.BaseQuestion: Dr. Bonaventura confirms that patients can leave a clinical trial if they so choose.
Response.Content: When a patient is enrolled in a clinical trial, the option always exists to leave, and the option's available at any point during that trial. If they become frightened, if they have side effects, and they become concerned that the side effects are seriously out of the norm, when compared to someone who is not in the trial, they can always leave the trial, and return to the standard treatment which is available today.

Response.BaseQuestion: Where do the ideas for this research come from?
Response.Content: Clinical trials come about because of the intellectual curiosity of physicians who see patients with problems. They'll see a patient with a problem, and wonder is there a drug that can be used to help this person, to change their lifespan, to make it longer? Is there a drug, or a technique that can be used to give them a better quality of life for the amount of time that we know they're going to have living with this disease? And it's just there, it's just the doctors, PhDs, who develop various technologies, who have an intellectual curiosity about changing the issues that human beings have to deal with.

Response.BaseQuestion: Dr. Bonaventura discusses safeguards that are in place for clinical trials.
Response.Content: There are rules and regulations for clinical trials, and in institutions there is something called the IRB, or the Institutional Review Board, which looks at what you want to do, how you want to do it, what is the patient population?, how is the drug going to be administered?, what is the technique that's going to be used? And this Board, is made up of physicians, scientists, sometimes laypeople, sometimes nurses. It's an entire group of people who, sit and look at what the person wants to study, and how they want to study it. It's this group of people who sign off on the study before it even gets to the general population.

Response.BaseQuestion: Are patients pressured into joining clinical trials?
Response.Content: When I offer a patient a clinical trial, there is no pressure for them to sign the paper, give us the consent immediately. Many patients are reluctant. They're in the office for the first, maybe second time, they're alone, we present the clinical trial, we go through it as best we can with them during that period of time. Sometimes people get confused when you give them a lot of information, particularly if you start using medical jargon. What we will do is tell the patient to take the form home, read it with whoever they need to read it with and explain it to that person, have that person call and ask questions of the clinical nurse, the doctor. Perhaps come back and have another discussion. There's no pressure to enroll in a clinical trial. It's offered, questions are answered, and it's encouraged, but patients do not need to participate if they do not want to after they've thought about it.

Response.BaseQuestion: Dr. Bonaventura on a patient's concern about being treated like a "Guinea pig."
Response.Content: Many times when we discuss clinical trials with patients, they have many questions, and understandably so. The most common question that I hear is, or the most common comment that I hear is, "I don't want to be a guinea pig, I don't want to be tested." "I don't want to undergo any new technology that hasn't been proven," and that's when the discussion about the fact that technologies, treatments have been evaluated in the past either in patients, animals, cadaver models, whatever the technique was, and that it's already been tested and it is ready to be used in human beings. We also discuss the fact that many times, if you're talking about a new drug regimen, particularly in the management of breast cancer, you may see a change in the order of the drugs, you may see a change in the dosage of the drugs, you may see a change in the interval in which the drug is being given to the patient. So it's not.... everything is not brand new. There may be just a little tweak of the system to change things in hopes for the better.

Response.BaseQuestion: Why is this research important?
Response.Content: If individuals did not participate in clinical trials, there would be no advancement to the science of medicine. We have to think about things like, we have to think about diseases like polio. If Jonas Salk hadn't done research into the polio virus, how it transmitted, and then ultimately come up with the polio vaccine, we would have a significant incidence of polio still in this country, and we no longer have that problem. Another disease is smallpox. We no longer have smallpox in this country, and it does exist in third-world countries, but not in this country. From the standpoint of the management of breast cancer, had those physicians not thought about decreasing the amount of surgery and treating with radiation, women would still be undergoing radical mastectomies. These operations were disfiguring and now we know, were not really necessary.

Response.BaseQuestion: Is there a downside to participating in a clinical trial?
Response.Content: As far as I'm concerned, there is no downside in participating in clinical trials. The studies, the clinical trials that are ready for "prime time" as we might call it, have been evaluated in animal models perhaps, in phase one trials. These drugs or treatments have already been tested and are ready to be used in large populations of patients, and I always recommend clinical trials to patients because, again, there are future generations that we need to think about, and as far as I'm concerned, there are no down...there is no downside to enrolling in a clinical trial.

Response.BaseQuestion: Would you participate in a clinical trial?
Response.Content:
I can honestly say to you that if I had a disease, process, or a new diagnosis with new technologies on the horizon, I would seriously consider enrolling in a clinical trial.
I would not hesitate to do that because, again, knowing the history, just of one disease, and by that I mean breast cancer, in my lifetime, the changes have been dramatic. The technologies have changed dramatically, and the treatments have changed dramatically, and because of that, I feel it is important to enroll in clinical trials, and I would definitely enroll in a clinical trial.

Response.BaseQuestion: As a physician, why are you involved in clinical trials research?
Response.Content: Part of the reason that I am involved in clinical trials is I am a university-based physician, and my practice is specific to patients with one disease process. When I see patients over and over again with the same disease, it makes me stop and think why is this happening? Is there something we can do to change it? Is there something we can do to decrease the problems and the issues that this patient is having? And it just forces you to, it forces me to think that there's got to be a better way, or an easier way for both the physician and the patient to be treated and to be taken care of.

Response.BaseQuestion: What about all the bad things you hear in the media about trials?
Response.Content: I think many times we hear about the bad things that happen in clinical trials. Many times I'll have patients come to my office, and they tell me about their neighbor's infection, or their neighbor's complication when they had the same procedure done and asked me why I'm not doing a certain X-ray when their neighbor had that X-ray, and it's the same sort of thing we tend to hear a lot about when things don't go perfectly - when everything isn't 100%. What we don't hear about are the trials that have been done, and have had excellent results. In the field of medicine, it's rare that anything is 100 percent. There are always possible complications. There are always possible side effects. And I think, as clinical investigators, and as patients enrolling in clinical trials, we need to understand that. But, we also need to understand that in the long run, that for a small amount of discomfort, or possible small or insignificant side effects, we can gain a lot of important information. And again, I really think the most important thing is no one ever tells you about the clinical trials that have been done with excellent results. And you only hear about the trials that, as the Vioxx situation presented where there were significant complications, deaths, et cetera.

Response.BaseQuestion: Are patients treated differently in clinical trials?
Response.Content: In the clinical trials, the patients are watched closely because we don't want to miss a side effect, a complication, a change in the status of the disease that we're evaluating. Are patients treated differently? I don't think they're different; I don't think they're treated differently as human beings, I just think they're treated differently because they're watched, perhaps a little more closely because they are enrolled in a clinical trial. And we have to document everything that is taking place in that person.

Response.BaseQuestion: What was your clinical trial about?
Response.Content: They were looking at the efficacy of two different drug combinations. One was Taxotere and Capecitabine and the second was Taxotere and Gemzar. And this was a cross-over clinical trial. So, the idea behind the crossover clinical trial was, you would be randomized into one drug regiment, and, after 3 or 4 months, you would be tested, and if that drug protocol didn't seem to be working for you, you would be transferred over to the other drug. So, it wasn't like you would be without options. And, that was one of the things that I liked about this clinical trial. And, so I read the information and I went through the whole process, in terms of talking with the nurse coordinator, talking with the doctor, reading as much information as I could, and I actually very quickly, within a couple of days, decided that this clinical trial was good for me.

Response.BaseQuestion: Null for specific cancers
Response.Content: Maybe it's best if you talk to your doctor about that topic or question.

Response.BaseQuestion: Null for other diseases
Response.Content: Maybe it's best if you talk to your doctor about that topic or question.

Response.BaseQuestion: What does it mean if my lymph nodes are positive?
Response.Content: Lymph nodes are small glands found throughout the body, they are part of the body's immune system. The lymph nodes in the armpit are the ones closest to the breast. If your lymph nodes are positive, it means that cancer cells have traveled from the original breast tumor to the nearby lymph nodes. This suggests that there is risk that tumor cells may have spread to other parts of your body.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What does it mean if my lymph nodes are negative?
What is an Axillary dissection?
What is a Sentinel lymph node biopsy?
What does it mean if my lymph nodes are negative?

Response.BaseQuestion: What does it mean if my lymph nodes are negative?
Response.Content: Lymph nodes are small glands found throughout the body, they are part of the body's immune system. The lymph nodes in the armpit are the ones closest to the breast. If your lymph nodes are negative it means the cancer cells were not found in the closest lymph nodes. Although this is a good finding and important, other factors are also considered by your physician in developing your treatment plan.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What does it mean if my lymph nodes are positive?
What is an Axillary dissection?
What is a Sentinel lymph node biopsy?

Response.BaseQuestion: What does Her-2 neu status reveal about my breast cancer?
Response.Content: Her-2 neu is a name for an important growth factor receptor. This is a gene within cells that determines how they grow, divide and repair themselves. Normally it is present in all cells. However, in 20 to 30% of breast cancers, there are too many copies of this gene within the breast cancer cell. Having too many copies means that your tumor will be called Her-2-positive.The result of this is that the breast cancer cell may grow faster and may be more likely to spread to other parts of the body. Breast cancer with this increased level of the Her-2 neu gene is also called a Her-2 neu overexpressing tumor. There is a treatment that is chosen specifically for Her-2 neu overexpressing tumors. The drug used in this treatment is called, Herceptin or trastuzumab. If a normal number of copies of this gene is found, your tumor will be called Her-2 negative.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What is targeted therapy and how does it work?

Response.BaseQuestion: What are the stages of breast cancer?
Response.Content: In order to treat breast cancer, doctors need to know the stage of the cancer. This is determined by the size of the cancer, whether lymph nodes are positive or negative and whether the cancer has spread to other parts of the body. The process of determining whether cancer cells have spread is called staging. Although it is good news if the staging tests do not reveal any spread of cancer, it is still possible that a few undetected breast cancer cells may have spread throughout the body. Staging is done through a variety of tests such as chest x-rays, blood work, and bone scans. Doctors use special language to communicate the information gathered from staging tests. In general terms, Stage . means that cancer cells were found in the breast, but were not found outside of the breast. Stage I. means that cancer cells have been found in the breast and in at least one of the lymph nodes in the armpit. Stage II. is used to describe a cancer where the breast tumor itself is large and often has positive armpit lymph nodes, or that the breast tumor has attached to parts of the chest wall. Inflammatory breast cancer is also considered Stage II.. Stage I. means that the breast cancer has spread to distant sites of the body such as bone, lungs or liver.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What does it mean if my lymph nodes are positive?
What does it mean if my lymph nodes are negative?
How do doctors describe tumors?

Response.BaseQuestion: What does ER or PR positive tell the doctor in terms of my treatment?
Response.Content:
The tissue from your tumor can be tested for specific characteristics about your breast cancer. Some tests look for receptors for hormones. Hormones influence the growth and development of tissues, such as the breast, that have receptors. Two important hormones in breast cancer are estrogen and progesterone. If your breast cancer cells have receptors for estrogen, it is called ER positive. If your tumor is found to be ER positive, treatment strategies to keep cancer cells from growing may block the estrogen receptors or decrease the amount of estrogen in your body. There are different drugs to treat ER positive breast cancers depending upon your menopausal status. For example, Tamoxifen is one of the drugs used in premenopausal women to block the estrogen receptor. Arimidex is an example of a drug used in postmenopausal women that decreases the amount of estrogen in the body. Breast cancer cells that don't have detectable estrogen receptors are called ER negative cells.
If your breast cancer cells have receptors for progesterone, it is called PR positive. ER positive and PR positive tumors are treated in the same manner. Breast cancer cells that don't have detectable progesterone receptors are called PR negative cells. If your hormone receptors are negative, you do not require hormonal treatment approaches for your breast cancer.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is an oncotype and how does that affect my treatment plan?
Response.Content: Oncotype is an analysis of your tumor for markers that may reflect how aggressively your tumor may behave and whether additional treatment may be indicated. This test may be performed on breast cancer tissue from women who are typically node negative. This test measures the level of important genes that determine the likelihood of the cancer to spread and the potential benefits of hormonal therapy or chemotherapy.

Response.BaseQuestion: What types of surgery done for breast cancer?
Response.Content: There are several different types of surgery that are performed for breast cancer. Today, the most common surgery is a lumpectomy. A lumpectomy is a breast-conserving surgery where the tumor and some surrounding normal tissue are removed leaving the majority of the breast intact. A mastectomy is a type of breast surgery where the entire breast is removed. Lymph nodes may be sampled with a limited procedure called a sentinel node biopsy. Sometimes a more complete removal of many lymph nodes in the armpit is advised using a procedure called an axillary dissection. The surgical approaches that are available today are a direct result of women participating in previous cancer clinical trials.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is neoadjuvant therapy?
Response.Content: Neoadjuvant therapy is a treatment given before an operation is done to remove the breast tumor. This approach is considered when shrinking the tumor prior to surgery may allow a less deforming or less invasive procedure to be done. For example, this may mean performing a lumpectomy instead of a mastectomy, or a sentinel node biopsy instead of an axillary dissection. Therefore, treatment before surgery may be desirable not only to preserve as much of the breast and lymph nodes as possible, but also to improve surgical recovery. The most common form of neoadjuvant therapy is chemotherapy. The neoadjuvant therapies that are available today are a direct result of women participating in previous cancer clinical trials.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is adjuvant therapy?
Response.Content: Adjuvant Therapy is treatment given after surgery to some patients where there is a chance that microscopic cancer cells may have spread. The goal of adjuvant therapy is to treat microscopic disease in order to reduce the risk of future recurrence. Research has allowed physicians to better predict which patients are more likely to benefit from receiving adjuvant therapy. Some of the factors that your physician will include in this decision are the size of your tumor, the number of lymph nodes involved, the ER and PR receptor status, and the Her-2 neu status. Hormonal treatments and chemotherapy are examples of adjuvant therapies. The adjuvant therapies that are available today are a direct result of women participating in previous cancer clinical trials.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is chemotherapy and how does it work?
Response.Content: Chemotherapy refers to drugs that kill cancer cells. Several drugs are often given at the same time and can reach cancer cells throughout the body. Chemotherapy drugs work in several different ways to destroy cancer cells. These include disrupting cancer cells by reducing tumor blood flow and turning off the internal chemical signals that promote growth. Chemotherapy drugs are given over a span of many weeks. Side effects are experienced when these drugs affect normal tissues as well. Frequent side effects of chemotherapy include decreased white blood counts with risk of infection, nausea and sometimes vomiting and hair loss. Some names of common chemotherapy drugs include: Doxorubicin, Cyclophosphamide, Docetaxel, and Paclitaxel. Your doctor may refer to these drugs by their brand name. For example, Doxorubicin is also known as Adriamycin.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is radiation therapy and how does it work?
Response.Content: Radiation is used after surgery to treat cancer cells that may be in the breast, chest wall or nearby lymph nodes. Even after the surgeon has removed the visible tumor, there may still be microscopic cancer cells in nearby tissue. These leftover cells can be killed by radiation. Radiation, like an X-ray, is most often administered from an external beam. This beam is directed carefully to avoid injury to other areas such as the heart or lungs. Each treatment takes only a few minutes but 25 to 30 treatments are required. Radiation damages cell DNA and this destroys cancer cells because intact DNA is necessary for cell survival. The most frequent side effects of radiation include local skin irritation like a sunburn, and sometimes increased fatigue.

RQ.BaseQuestion: How do doctors know if a patient needs radiation or hormonal therapy?

Response.BaseQuestion: What is hormone therapy and how does it work?
Response.Content: Hormones naturally influence the growth and development of sex tissues, such as the breast. Breast cancer may be fueled by the two hormones produced by women, estrogen and progesterone. Hormone therapy is a cancer treatment that blocks or removes this hormonal stimulation of the cancer cells. The most frequent side effects of hormone therapy include blood clots, abnormal uterine bleeding, and hot flashes/mood changes. Some names of common hormone therapy drugs are Tamoxifen, Anastrozole, Letrozole, Exemestane, and Raloxifene.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is targeted therapy and how does it work?
Response.Content: Targeted therapies combat tumor cell growth by attacking specific features of a person's breast cancer. For example, the drug Herceptin or trastuzumab targets cancers which have more of a growth factor, Her-2 neu, than is present in normal breast tissue. Unlike chemotherapy drugs, targeted therapies can destroy cancer cells with minimal effect on healthy cells. However, the limitation of these therapies is that they only work on cancers with the features they were designed to target.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What does Her-2 neu status reveal about my breast cancer?

Response.BaseQuestion: How have past clinical trials significantly changed breast cancer surgery and treatment?
Response.Content: Clinical trials have changed the way breast cancer is treated completely from the way it was treated over 50 years ago. Fifty years ago, women used to have a radical mastectomy, that is, their entire breast, the underlying chest wall, the lymph nodes were removed. There were terrible problems with lymphedema, which is a swelling of the arm and the chest wall, as well as terrible cosmetic problems. Fifty years of clinical trials have proven that we can do less surgery on women, much less disfiguring surgery. Most women now have a lumpectomy, and what's called a sentinel lymph node dissection, which is far less severe and cosmetically damaging. We have a good idea of which women will require chemotherapy to help prevent their cancer from coming back. We also have a much better idea of which women require hormonal therapy or anti-hormonal therapy, like Tamoxifen and drugs like Arimidex (anastrozole). We actually have a very good idea of who to treat, who will benefit from all of this. And in fact, the survival of women because of clinical trials has improved about 30 percent to 40 percent in the last 25 to 30 years.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is an Axillary dissection?
Response.Content: An axillary dissection is a surgical procedure to determine whether cancer cells have spread to the lymph nodes under your arm. In an axillary dissection many nodes, often 10 or more, are removed and examined for the presence of cancer cells.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What is a Sentinel lymph node biopsy?
What does it mean if my lymph nodes are positive?
What does it mean if my lymph nodes are negative?

Response.BaseQuestion: What is a Sentinel lymph node biopsy?
Response.Content: A sentinel lymph node biopsy is a surgical procedure to determine whether cancer cells have spread to the lymph nodes under your arm. With this procedure, a substance is injected near the breast tumor. This substance may be radioactive or it may be a dye. The radioactive substance or dye flows through the lymphatic ducts to the lymph nodes. The first node to receive the substance or dye is removed and examined by the pathologist. If no cancer cells are found, further surgery on the lymph nodes is not recommended. A sentinel lymph node biopsy is done to spare patients from having to undergo the more extensive axillary dissection. However, if cancer cells are found in the sentinel lymph node, most often more lymph nodes will be removed during an axillary dissection.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is a SERM or Selective Estrogen Receptor Modulator?
Response.Content: SERM stands for Selective Estrogen Receptor Modulator and is a form of hormone therapy. A commonly used SERM is Tamoxifen. SERMs block the estrogen receptors found in the breast cells. Unfortunately, some SERMs also act on other estrogen receptors in uterine endometrial cells and can stimulate abnormal growth.

Response.BaseQuestion: How do doctors describe tumors?
Response.Content: Staging and grading are used to describe tumors. Stage is the extent of the disease using uniform terms. TNM is a common classification system. T stands for tumor size. When the numbers 1 through 4 follow the letter T, higher numbers mean larger tumors. N stands for Nodes, that is, the number and location of lymph nodes that have cancer cells. When the numbers 0 through 3 follow the letter N, higher numbers mean more lymph nodes that contain cancer. M stands for metastases. If 0 is after M it means no metastases have been found, while 1 after M means that the cancer has spread beyond the breast and lymph nodes to other parts of the body.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is the role of the pathologist?
Response.Content: When breast tissue or lymph nodes are removed by the surgeon, they are examined by the pathologist using a microscope. The pathologist determines whether the specimen contains cancer cells and classifies the type of cancer.

Response.BaseQuestion: When a woman is diagnosed with breast cancer today, does she benefit from the participation of other women that took part in the previous breast cancer trials?
Response.Content: When a woman is diagnosed with breast cancer today, she clearly benefits from the thousands, if not tens of thousands, of women that have gone before her in clinical trials. In fact, in Pittsburgh, which has been a center of clinical trials in breast cancer for over 50 years, nearly 10,000 women have been enrolled on trials that clearly have set the new standards of care for all women with breast cancer in this time period.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is a MUGA scan?
Response.Content: The MUGA or Multiple Uptake Gated Acquisition scan produces a moving image of the beating heart so that doctors can see how well the heart is working prior to making chemotherapy recommendations. The scan involves injecting a low-level radioactive substance called Technetium 99 into the bloodstream. The patient's heart is then viewed under a gamma camera that detects the radiation of the Technetium 99 and creates an image of the blood as it moves through the heart and heart valves.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is a tissue expander
Response.Content: A tissue expander is a device that surgeons use to stretch the skin of the breast. This allows the surgeon to later insert a breast implant to reconstruct the breast.

Response.BaseQuestion: What does double blind mean?
Response.Content: A double blind clinical trial is a type of randomized clinical trial in which neither the physician nor the patient knows which treatment option the patient has been assigned to receive. In a double blind trial, the investigational drug and the standard drug are formulated to look the same. This type of trial is done to reduce the possibility of bias.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What is an investigational agent?

Response.BaseQuestion: What is an investigational agent?
Response.Content: An investigational agent is a medication that has not yet been approved for use with a specific disease or condition by the FDA. Many clinical trials utilize investigational agents alone, or in combination with standard medications

Response.BaseQuestion: What is a principal investigator/co-investigator
Response.Content: The principal investigator is the person in charge of the entire research study. The co-investigator is a physician or staff member who is working with the principal investigator on the research study.

RQ.BaseQuestion: Who will take care of me on a clinical trial?

Response.BaseQuestion: What is NSABP?
Response.Content: The National Surgical Adjuvant Breast and Bowel Project or NSABP is a large network of researchers, physicians, and health care professionals at public and private institutions across the country who work toward the common goal of controlling, effectively treating, and ultimately curing breast and colorectal cancer. NSABP is supported by the National Cancer Institute and has its headquarters in Pittsburgh, PA.

Response.BaseQuestion: How is participating in a clinical trial different from getting standard treatment?
Response.Content: Patients who participate in clinical trials undergo a similar experience as those in standard care. In both cases, patients receive treatment for their cancer. Cancer treatments today involve therapies that may cause side effects. All patients being treated for cancer receive close observation. However, there are some key differences between clinical trials and standard treatment. Patients in a clinical trial are required to review and sign a lengthy and detailed research consent form. In addition, there may be side effects that are unanticipated on the clinical trial. For this reason, patients on clinical trials may be monitored more frequently and are sometimes required to come in to the clinic more often. They may undergo more frequent testing than patients on standard therapy. In either case, patients generally report that they receive excellent care whether they are on a clinical trial or receiving standard treatment.

RQ.BaseQuestion: Will all the risks and side effects be explained to me?

Response.BaseQuestion: Who will have access to the information that the study gathers about me?
Response.Content: Any group that has provided funds to a research study, such as the National Institute of Health, private foundations, or drug companies, may access the study records to ensure that researchers are conducting the study properly. This is known as a study audit. Also, groups that oversee subject safety, such as Institutional Review Boards, need to have access to study records so that they can evaluate whether correct procedures are being followed. Consent forms list any group that may request your study records.

Response.BaseQuestion: What happens if I say "no"?
Response.Content: That's okay, If they say no at the beginning, before they even enroll, they still get the standard of care which is the chemotherapy. They can decide at any time to stop. We don't force people to do clinical trials. We don't get mad at them if they decide they don't want to do the trials anymore. Every woman that I treat has a choice at any time to stop her clinical trial.

Response.BaseQuestion: Can you explain the difference between adjuvant and neoadjuvant therapy?
Response.Content: Adjuvant therapy is therapy after you've had primary surgery to remove your cancer. For example, you've had a lumpectomy or a mastectomy, you've had a lymph node dissection, and your cancer essentially is gone. What adjuvant therapy tries to do is to kill off any little bits of cancer that may be somewhere else in your body that we can't see. That's called adjuvant therapy. Neoadjuvant therapy, on the other hand, is systemic therapy, be it chemotherapy or anti-hormonal therapy, before surgery. The goals of neoadjuvant therapy are to try to shrink the cancer before we do surgery. If you came in with a really large breast cancer, the size of a tennis ball in your breast, (thankfully, I see that not as often in people as I used to) we would want to shrink your cancer down with chemotherapy before surgery. We also do neoadjuvant chemotherapy to try to see if the chemo works. That's why it's a very good time for us to try new things, because what we do is we test a neoadjuvant therapy, how many people respond to the cancer, and how many people have their cancer go away completely.

Response.BaseQuestion: What are the advantages and disadvantages of adjuvant therapy?
Response.Content: The major advantage of adjuvant therapy is that it is systemic, so it kills off any cancer cells. The idea is to kill off any cancer cells that are anywhere in your body that we can't see. Because, when you come in after having had breast cancer, a question people ask all the time is, How do you know it's nowhere else in my body. Well, we would either do an x-ray or a CAT-scan, maybe a bone scan to be sure it's not in your bones. If it's nowhere else, there still might be little microscopic bits of it somewhere else in your body, and you need the therapy that goes all throughout your body to be sure that there's no cancer cells left, that they're all killed. The idea behind adjuvant therapy is that it kills off all of the little microscopic bits of cancer that we can't see. The disadvantage, if any, of adjuvant therapy is like that of any therapy, it might have toxicity. With chemotherapy your hair will more than likely fall out, nine times out of ten. Chemotherapy sometimes suppresses the white cells of your blood, makes you a little bit more prone to infection temporarily. Those are the disadvantages of any adjuvant therapy that we may use.

Response.BaseQuestion: Why would you recommend adjuvant therapy to one of your patients?
Response.Content: I would recommend adjuvant therapy to one of my patients because I know that if she goes through, 4 months of chemotherapy, or 6 months of chemotherapy, or 5 years of an anti-hormonal therapy like Tamoxifen, her chance of the cancer coming back will go down dramatically. And because of adjuvant therapy now, we can tell most women that they have an 85 to 90 percent chance that their cancer will never come back. That's what I tell women now. It's great. It's just a matter of what you have to go through, whether you have to go through anti-hormonal therapy like Tamoxifen, if you have to go through Tamoxifen plus chemotherapy, or something else like that. That's really why I give women adjuvant therapy.

Response.BaseQuestion: What can patients expect if they receive adjuvant treatment?
Response.Content: Patients can expect a number of things depending on the adjuvant treatment. If it's chemotherapy, generally it's anywhere from 4 to 8 doses of chemotherapy, usually given every 3 weeks, although sometimes we give it every 2 weeks, sometimes, we give it weekly. It really depends on the kind of chemotherapy they get. With the modern chemotherapies for breast cancer at least, it's likely that you're going to lose your hair. And believe me, we've tried everything from ice packs on people's heads to running around the clinic to try to prevent them from their hair falling out, but it's likely your hair will fall out. It's also likely with chemotherapy that it will suppress the white cells in your blood, making you a little bit more prone to infection. If a chemotherapy cycle, that is, the number of days between chemotherapy is 3 weeks, usually your white cells are at their lowest about 10 days after you start, and that's when you're most prone to infection. It doesn't mean you can't go out and do all the things you normally do. It just means that if you're not feeling well, we ask you to take your temperature, and if it's above 100 or 101, call your doctor, and we check your white cells to see if they're too low.

Response.BaseQuestion: If a patient said no to adjuvant therapy, what would her options be?
Response.Content: Generally, if a patient says no to adjuvant therapy that's her decision. What I try to do when people come to me is to lay out for them all of the choices that they have. Generally, if a woman comes in to me and has positive lymph nodes with cancer that are involved under her arm, and she is fairly young, and her cancer does not express the receptor for estrogen. In that particular woman, she would get probably a substantial benefit from chemotherapy. But if she doesn't want to do that, that's her choice. Your chances of it never coming back in ten years are 90 percent with chemotherapy, 60 or 70 percent without, and that's a 20-30 percent benefit. That's your choice if you want to do it. I'm still going to treat you the same way, you can still come to the clinic every four to six months for the first several years, and every 6 months for a couple years after that. We'll still do mammograms on you once a year, or in some cases, MRI scans of your breasts once a year. But, if you don't want to do chemotherapy, your risk of reoccurrence is higher. And if someone says, Look, I don't want to do it. That's okay. I mean, it's a little bit more difficult when you're older, and when the side effects of chemotherapy maybe are a little bit worse. In that case, if the benefit is only 2 or 3 percent, some women, from chemotherapy or any adjuvant therapy, some women say, Look, I don't want to do it for 2 or 3 percent. Everybody has a different feeling about what that percentage is so that's why I view it as my role as an oncologist to say, Look, these are your options. This is the percentage chance that you have, if you do X, Y, or .. .And some women say yes and some women say no.

Response.BaseQuestion: What are some of the factors that impact a patient's treatment plan?
Response.Content: When a breast cancer patient comes to me, and I try to devise a treatment plan, there are a few things that come into play. Obviously, the stage of her cancer, how aggressive it is under the microscope. That's the grade, actually. How far it's spread. That's the stage of cancer. Her desires. Some women really want a minimalist approach. They just want to take as minimum therapy as possible. Other women come in and say, I want everything possible. We take that into account. We also take into account the overall health of a woman, what we call her performance status, or her ability to tolerate therapy. And these are the sort of things that we put together, when we come up with a treatment plan for you.

Response.BaseQuestion: How do doctors know if a patient needs radiation or hormonal therapy?
Response.Content: We know if a woman needs radiation, because there are specific criteria. For example, if a woman has had a lumpectomy, she'll need radiation therapy. If a woman has had a mastectomy, and had a primary cancer greater than 5 centimeters, she'll need radiation to the wall of her chest. If a woman has more than 4 lymph nodes involved, she'll need radiation to the wall of her chest. Generally, most women, who have estrogen receptor positive breast cancers, are women who would need some sort of anti-hormonal therapy.

Response.BaseQuestion: Should patients consider a double mastectomy?
Response.Content: Mastectomy or not, and especially double mastectomy, is a very individualized decision. There are certain women, again, our role is to A) say what the risk of local reoccurrence is in a woman's breast after having a lumpectomy, and B) what's the risk of cancer in the other breast if she doesn't do anything. With newer techniques like MRI scans, we can tell whether there's cancer in the other breast many years, probably before it comes clinically apparent. It's really a women's choice. I've had women who say, I don't want to lose my breasts. I've had women who have had a cancer or sometimes a reoccurring cancer in the same breast that have said, I just don't want to deal with this anymore. or I prefer to have a bilateral mastectomy., and in some cases not have a reconstruction. Some cases have a reconstruction, have new breasts. It's really a very personal decision. Again, we try to do, and what most of the people at Magee's Breast Cancer Center try to do, is really work with a woman to try to figure out what she really wants at the end of the day and try to help her make that decision. But in the end of the day, it's her decision.

Response.BaseQuestion: What is cancer?
Response.Content: Cancer is not just one disease but many diseases. Cancer begins in your cells, which are the building blocks of your body. Normally, your body forms new cells as you need them, replacing old cells that die. Sometimes this process goes wrong. New cells grow even when you don't need them, and old cells don't die when they should. These extra cells can form a mass called a tumor. There are more than 100 different types of cancer. Most cancers are named for the organ or type of cell in which they start - for example, cancer that begins in the colon is called colon cancer. When a cancer that starts in one place spreads to another, it's called metastases. This site discusses clinical trials that are designed to find improved treatments breast for cancer.

Response.BaseQuestion: What does invasive breast cancer mean?
Response.Content: Breast cancer is either invasive or non-invasive. Non-invasive breast cancer are contained within the duct or lobule of the breast where they originate. Invasive breast cancers have spread into the supporting tissue beyond the ducts or lobules and possibly beyond the breast such as to the axillary lymph nodes or other tissues.

Response.BaseQuestion: Will I die?

Response.BaseQuestion: If I participate in a clinical trial do I get to make any decisions about my treatment?
Response.Content: You always have the right to decide if you will stay in the trial. But when you sign up for a clinical trial, the day-to-day decisions about your treatment are determined by the protocol. It's important that you follow the schedule precisely. If you're not able to fulfill the protocol requirements, a clinical trial may not be the best option for you.

Response.BaseQuestion: Can I stop participating in the trial?
Response.Content:
You can decide to withdraw your participation in a clinical trial at any time. This will not jeopardize your future care by your physician or at the institute where you receive your care. Never, ever feel trapped in a clinical trial; there are lots of reasons why you might decide to withdraw. If you decide that you can't continue, make sure to tell the doctor or nurse your reasons for leaving. It will help with future studies.
Dr. Bonaventura: When a patient is enrolled in a clinical trial, the option always exists to leave, and the option's available at any point during that trial. If they become frightened, if they have side effects, and they become concerned that the side effects are seriously out of the norm, when compared to someone who is not in the trial, they can always leave the trial, and return to the standard treatment which is available today.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What are my rights as a participant?
Can I stay in the trial if I move to a different city?
What happens if I miss some appointments?

Response.BaseQuestion: Will the doctor tell the truth about the trial?
Response.Content: Physicians and researchers must keep you up to date about every part of the study to the best of their knowledge. If you have any questions about the trial, ask your research team.

RQ.BaseQuestion: Can the doctor switch treatment without telling me?
Will all the risks and side effects be explained to me?

Response.BaseQuestion: What's the next step if I agree to participate?
Response.Content:
Once you decide to participate in a trial, you will be asked to sign a consent form. Treatment will usually begin within a few days after the consent has been signed. However, it may be necessary to have additional testing performed related to your participation before treatment begins.
[Dr. Bonaventura] When I think a patient is a candidate for a clinical trial, what I normally do is explain the trial to them, and explain the rationale for the trial. Then what we do is we sit, we go through the consent form, and we go through what exactly the patient will have to deal with when she or he becomes involved in this trial. Is blood work going to be drawn? Are X-Rays going to be taken? Will measurements be taken? Whatever the trial involves, we go through that. The goal is to prepare the patient for exactly what will happen to him or her.

RQ.BaseQuestion: What is the consent form?

Response.BaseQuestion: Who can help me decide what's best for me?
Response.Content:
If you are trying to decide about joining a clinical trial, there are many places to go for help. The research team of a particular trial will tell you all about the treatment being tested. They can tell you anything you want to know; such as risks and benefits, and the steps of the clinical trial. Your family doctor may be able to give you further advice. And don't forget your friends, family, and support network. Those closest to you can be there to listen as you work through your own concerns. At the end of the day, the decision is yours. But, you are not in this alone. Rely on those around you to help.
Anne: I did not seek any help with the consent form. And, I also did not talk to my family about whether or not I should be in the clinical trial because I felt that this is my decision, and this is a decision between me and my oncologist. And, I felt very firm about that. And, I really did not want to get into a position where I had friends and family weighing in on what they thought I should do.
Barbara: How I went about making a decision about entering the clinical trial was my family. My family, my mother and my sister, we talked about it. My sister and my mother accompanied me to each and every doctor's appointment, chemotherapy treatment, yes.

Response.BaseQuestion: Why did you participate in a clinical trial?
Response.Content:
[Anne] I thought it was my best treatment option. I thought it was going to, I thought it was my best treatment option. And, probably my doctor. He just, he felt that I would benefit from being in this trial, and because he's been my doctor for over six years, I know the reputation he has as a researcher, that he does, has done a number of clinical trials, I just thought that this would, that he knew what he was doing and that this would be a good thing for me.
So, well, the benefit to me is, if this drug works, I'm right there on the cutting edge, getting all the benefits of the drug therapy. As well as, for other people, they'll have that information. So it worked for this population of people, and you know, they; they've done very well, and so, it might ultimately be effective enough treatment that it becomes standard care, until something better comes along.
[Barbara] Because me, as being an African-American woman, wanted them to have some research on African American women to help with the medication, the type of treatment that we, that they can give us to help us. Looking back on it, yes I believe it was the best thing for me to do. Would I do it again? Yes I would.
[Shannon] Well, I would like to see that, you know, obviously you want to see a cure, but I would be more realistic in hoping that maybe the treatments that I'm receiving and the combination of drugs they're using on me, will benefit someone else with the same type of cancer that I have. So, whether or not it does help somebody in the future, I really want it to help me first. So, I'm more concerned about me. But on the other hand, I'll do my good deed for society and you know, do the clinical study. Which is why I participated in it; which is why I'm sitting here talking to you guys, against my better judgement
[Lettie] My daughter-in-law, she, well I went home and I talked to my family about the trial, you know, what I should do, and my daughter-in-law, she said, "Well I think they'd follow you closer if you was on the trial." And like, when you say cancer, it's like a scary something anyway. You know, it's just something like, you don't expect to hear it happening to you. I talked about everything with my family, everything, from day one, from the day I was diagnosed. My family was there with me for every treatment, everything. Every time with the doctor there was a family member there with me. Whatever I had to do there was family there. She said, my daughter-in-law felt like, "Maybe you should give it a try." And I did.

Response.BaseQuestion: Would you recommend a clinical trial to a friend?
Response.Content:
Barbara: If I knew someone that was diagnosed with cancer and they were offered the opportunity to participate in a clinical trial research I would encourage them to participate.
What I think we gain with people participating in clinical trial research is the doctors, the medical field getting the information they need to help us as citizens or people with cancer, better treat us, better diagnosis.
If someone asked me my opinion about being in a clinical trial research, I would encourage them to join the research. Why would I encourage them? My personal opinion is that think you'll be treated better. They'll look at you closer. They'll watch your blood work, how you reacting to the treatments, and they'll get some information that they need too but I think it's a benefit to you to join the clinical trial research.
Anne: I would definitely recommend a clinical trial to, This is what I would recommend, if they are diagnosed with cancer, or any other kind of a disease, where they are eligible for a clinical trial, I would definitely recommend that they stay open to hearing everything about the trial, what the aims of the trial are, as well as also understanding what the current standard treatment is and what that will provide for them as well.
I guess, what I would just, what I would reiterate is, clinical trials are another treatment option, and they often provide you with the latest and the greatest therapies that are being looked at. And they can provide a lot of benefit, and so they're definitely something worth exploring.
Shannon: Well, you already have cancer, it's a done deal. It can't get any worse, period. So you got to have choices, and if you have the choice of a clinical trial, then what's it going to do? It can't hurt you, as long as you're well informed and you understand what you're getting into, it can't hurt you, you've already got cancer. You should, at that point it's getting better and helping other people. And if you can do both at the same time, I think that's a pretty good deal.
There's, I mean, I just think the clinical study is just the perfect opportunity to you know, help yourself, and to help medical science. I mean, its, there's no real reason not to do it. I don't know why you wouldn't do it. I'm sure there is. I'm sure that somebody has come up with a reason not to do it, or there would be more people doing it probably. But I couldn't come up with a reason not to do it. It's helping me personally, you know, currently I'm involved in it, and it's helping me so, I would suggest it to anybody.
Lettie: The only thing I can tell anybody about clinical trials is do your homework, think it over, and see whatever is the best thing for you. I wouldn't advise no one to just sign the papers. Think about what is best for you. Do you think this may help you? And being that my sister had breast cancer five years before I got breast cancer.

Response.BaseQuestion: Who decides what clinical trials are available?
Response.Content: Clinical trials come about because of the intellectual curiosity of physicians who see patients with problems. They'll see a patient with a problem, and wonder is there a drug that can be used to help this person, to change their lifespan, to make it longer? Is there a drug, or a technique that can be used to give them a better quality of life for the amount of time that we know they're going to have living with this disease? And it's just there, it's just the doctors, PhDs, who develop various technologies, who have an intellectual curiosity about changing the issues that human beings have to deal with.

Response.BaseQuestion: Welcome Back
Response.Content: Welcome back to this site on breast cancer clinical trials. I encourage you to continue to explore the topics and ask your questions.
I'm not sure which answer to offer first. Which question is closest to yours?
Maybe it's best if you talk to your doctor about that topic or question.
We're here to talk about clinical trials and I'll be happy to talk to you about that.
